questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with reference to the development of the brain?

choices.text: The superior cerebellar peduncles develops from the metencephalon
The rhombomeres 2 and 3 contains the motor nucleus of the facial nerve
The cervical flexure is present between the metencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord
The pontine flexure is directed ventrally between the metencephalon and myelencephalon

questions.solution:
During the development of the brain, the pontine flexure is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon parts, of the rhombencephalon, and is directed ventrally.

The developing brain consists of three major divisions: prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain).

  • The prosencephalon gives rise to the telencephalon, diencephalon 1 (D1) and diencephalon 2 (D2), which has three subdivisions.
  • The mesencephalon is subdivided into mesencephalon 1 (M1) and mesencephalon 2 (M2).
  • The rhombencephalon is subdivided into the isthmusrhombencephali and rhombomeres 1–8.

The following table shows derivatives of the cerebral regions from caudal to rostral

Note: Newer studies oppose the older model of brain development and suggest that instead of 3 anatomical divisions, it is better to divide it into anterior and posterior divisions. 

The pattern of the distribution of the motor nuclei associated with the rhombomeres is as follows:

Division of the rhombomeres Associated motor nuclei
Rhombomere 1 Trochlear nucleus
Rhombomeres 2 and 3 Trigeminal nucleus
Rhombomeres 4 and 5 Facial nucleus
Rhombomere 5 Abducens nucleus
Rhombomeres 6 and 7 Glossopharyngeal nucleus
Rhombomeres 7 and 8 Vagal, accessory, and hypoglossal nuclei

Flexures of the developing brain:

The prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon are initially arranged craniocaudally, which is altered by the formation of various flexures as below:

  • Cervical flexure: Present between the myelencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord.
  • Cephalic flexure: Also known as mesencephalic flexure. It is present in the region of midbrain and is concave ventrally.
  • Pontine flexure: It is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon
  • Telencephalic flexure: It occurs between the telencephalon and the diencephalon.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with hyperuricemia, except?
questions.solution:
• In Adenosine deaminase deficiency the adenosine cannot be converted to its deaminated metabolites and hence not associated with increased uric acid production, so hyperuricemia is not seen.
  • Adenosine deaminase deficiency is associated with Severe immunodeficiency.
Causes of hyperuricemia
1° Hyperuricemia 2° Hyperuricemia
  • Over activity of PRPP synthetase
  • Partial deficiency of HGPRT
  • Increased cell turn-over: Leukemia, Psoriasis, Polycythemia Vera
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Radiotherapy & chemotherapy leads to tumor lysis syndrome which causes urate nephropathy
  • Hereditary fructose intolerance( caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase-B.)
  • Salicylates (underexcretion)

Hyperuricemia due to both overproduction & underexcretion:

  • Von-Gierke disease(Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency disease)
  • G6PD deficiency
  • Alcohol

questions.text: False regarding the given below instrument

choices.text: It is used in sharp dilatation and curettage
It is held between the thumb and the first 2 fingers
It is guided into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the cavity's lateral aspect
Uterine perforation may occur and is suspected when instrument travels deeper than previously measured

questions.solution:
The instrument is "Sims uterine sound".

It is used in dilatation and curettage. The instrument can cause uterine perforation and is hence introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced. It is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers.

After introducing the instrument, a gentle resistance is felt when it meets the fundus and the distance from the fundus to external os is measured by score marks along the length of the sound.

questions.text: All the following are features of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia except

choices.text: Restrictive changes in pulmonary function test

questions.solution:
•  Males are predominantly affected (4:1) in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical Pulmonary eosinophilia:

  • It is seen in persons infected with lymph node dwelling filarial species
  • Males are predominantly affected (4:1)
  • Nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough
  • Weight loss, low grade fever, adenopathy
  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities, increased bronchovascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titres
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in lungs and hence not found in blood
  • Treatment: Diethyl carbamazine

questions.text: How would you classify the following according to the DeBakey classification?
questions.solution:
The above image shows proximal dissection of only the ascending aorta. This is classified as type II as per DeBakey's classification.

 Classification of aortic dissection:

  • Stanford Type A - proximal lesions. These are more common and dangerous. It may involve:
    • Both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey type I
    • Only the ascending aorta - DeBakey type II
  • Stanford Type B or DeBakey type III - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery

questions.text: At PHCs, vaccines are stored in:
questions.solution:
• Ice lined refrigerators (ILRs) are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centres (PHCs).
  • ILRs are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius for storage of vaccines.
  • They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.
  • The ILRs are lined ice packs or tubes.
  • Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR .

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of dermatomyositis, except:
questions.solution:
Salmon rash is not a dermatological manifestation of Dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of Dermatomyositis:

A. Pathognomonic manifestations

  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules

B. Characteristic manifestations

  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms(Shawl distribution)
  • Heliotrope rash: Purplish color rash, often itchy, associated with swelling around the eye.
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

C. Compatible manifestations

  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

D. Less common Manifestations

  • Facial swelling
  • Malignancy
  • Erythroderma
  • Lichen planus

The salmon rash is seen in guttate psoriasis and still's disease.

Picture of the patient with still's disease showing salmon rash on her face and trunk:

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A man has severe hypertension. The scale of measurement used for severity is:
questions.solution:
• The scale used for severity is an ordinal scale as there is a meaningful order but, no absolute quantities when arranging data as severe, moderate, mild, etc.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Socratic method of communication?
questions.solution:
Didactic methods are methods of one-way communication. Lectures and demonstration are the most common example of this method.

Socratic methods are methods of two-way communication which include a symposium, panel discussions, workshops, and group discussion.

questions.text: A surgeon during an appendectomy on a 20-year-old performs an oblique muscle cutting incision. Which of the following is the likely incision performed?
questions.solution:
Rutherford Morison’s incision is essentially an oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary

It is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. All layers are divided in the line of the incision. If better access is required, it is possible to convert the gridiron to a Rutherford Morison incision by cutting the internal oblique and transversus muscles in the line of the incision.

Rockey Davis incision- Transverse muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant

  • 1 is Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - the most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) an oblique incision(superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. 
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old manual laborer is brought to the ER with confusion, drowsiness, and oliguria. He was working in the sun throughout the day. His examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Pulse: 124 bpm

BP: 100/60 mmHg

Core temperature: 106°F

Sweating: present
questions.solution:
In the given patient with a history of exertion in the sun, along with a core temperature >105°F and the presence of sweating, a diagnosis of exertional heat stroke is most likely. 

In exertional heat stroke (EHS), the affected patients are usually previously healthy and have a history of strenuous exertion in the heat — such as military recruits, laborers, and athletes. Despite being severely dehydrated, most patients present with diaphoresis. Muscular exertion can cause rhabdomyolysis and consequent complications such as hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Creatine kinase is elevated and patients may have features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Renal failure can occur due to rhabdomyolysis, direct thermal injury, or volume depletion. These patients might also present with hepatic injury because of the sensitivity of hepatocytes to heat.

Classical heat stroke (option D) differs from EHS in that it usually occurs in older patients with predisposing health factors. These patients often present with anhidrosis despite high temperatures. They usually don't have abnormal electrolytes or coagulopathy unless the presentation is delayed. 

Heat syncope (option A) is when the patient collapses following exercise or prolonged standing in the heat. It is usually seen in elderly patients. It occurs due to volume depletion and peripheral vasodilation, causing postural hypotension.  

Heat exhaustion (option B) differs from heat stroke in that the thermoregulatory control measures are still functional and there is no CNS dysfunction. The core temperature is elevated but is <105°F. The diagnosis of heat exhaustion is made in a patient after excluding the presence of any symptoms that might indicate heat stroke.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding anticoagulant use in pregnant women with prosthetic valves except

choices.text: Warfarin is the most effective anticoagulant for preventing maternal thromboembolic complications
Heparin is less hazardous for the fetus
Heparin needs to be discontinued just before delivery
Warfarin is contraindicated during breast feeding

questions.solution:
UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH (low molecular weight heparin) and Warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breast-feeding.

Anticoagulation is crucial for women with mechanical prosthetic valves.

Warfarin is the most effective anticoagulant for preventing maternal thromboembolic complications but it causes significant fetal morbidity and mortality.

Anticoagulation with heparin is less hazardous for the fetus but the risk of maternal thromboembolic complications is much higher.

The most recent guidelines of American college of chest physicians for the management of pregnant women with mechanical prosthetic valves offer several different treatment options.

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and to replace it by heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to 12th week. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) can also be used.
  • This is then replaced by warfarin tablet 3 mg. daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks.
  • Thereafter it is replaced by heparin which is discontinued just before delivery (6 hours). If delivery supervenes when anticoagulant is still effective, the antidote protamine sulfate can be used to counter extensive bleeding.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
  • UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH and Warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breast-feeding.

questions.text: Upper middle class score in Kuppuswamy’s scale is:
questions.solution:
• The score for upper middle class according to Kuppuswamy’s SES scale is 16 – 25.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: First gene based therapy approved for clinical use
questions.solution:
Tisagenlecleucel is the first gene based therapy that is approved for use in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Mechanism of tisagenlecleucel’s action:

  • It is a CD19-directed genetically modified autologous T cell immunotherapy which involves reprogramming a patient’s own T cells with a transgene encoding a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) to identify and eliminate CD19-expressing malignant and normal cells.
  • Use: Treatment of patients up to age 25 years with B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) that is refractory or in second or later relapse.
  • Option a and c: Cyclophosphamide and chlorambucil are alkylating agents.
  • Option d: Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin.
  • It is a fusion protein in which the receptor binding domain of diphtheria toxin (DT) has been exchanged for that of the interleukin-2 (IL-2) molecule. 
  • Denileukin diftitox (Ontak) directs the cytocidal action of diphtheria toxin to cells which express the IL-2 receptor.
  • Used for treatment of cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A patient of acute leukemia is admitted with febrile neutropenia. On day four of being treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, his fever increases. X-ray chest shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates. Which of the following should be the most appropriate next step in the management:
questions.solution:
• The history of acute leukemia with febrile neutropenia (immunocompromised state) with bilateral fluffy infiltrates on chest X-ray and failing to improve with broad spectrum antibiotics probably gives clue that patient is suffering from pulmonary infection due to P. jirovecii.
  • Hence most appropriate line of treatment should be addition of Cotrimoxazole for treatment.
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ or Cotrimoxazole) and pentamidine isothionate are the drugs of choice for the treatment of acute cases of pneumocystis pneumonia.
  • TMP-SMZ is also used as prophylaxis in the management of HIV infected individuals.

questions.text: The milestone of object permanence develops in a child at:
questions.solution:
• The milestone of cognitive development called object permanence develops in a child at around 9 months.
  • Object permanence is the recognition that objects continue to exist even after they are out of sight.
  • It is also called constancy.
  • It is with this understanding that children begin to search and persist for things that are hidden.

questions.text: All of the following structures are pierced during the administration of the spinal anesthesia except
questions.solution:
Posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced while administering the spinal anesthesia.

Spinal anesthesia, also known as subarachnoid blockade or spinal block is a type of regional anesthesia in which the lower half of the body is anesthetized by injecting an anesthetic agent in the subarachnoid space surrounding the spinalcord.

Anatomical considerations and structures pierced:

  • The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2 in adults (L3 in infants) and the dural space extends down to S2 (lower in children). 
  • Therefore, the subarachnoid space between L2 and S2 contains only CSF and lumbar and sacral nerve roots (cauda equina).
  • The line joining the iliac crests (intercristine or Tuffier’s line) is at the L3/L4 interspace.
  • The order of the structures pierced by the needle before it reaches the subarachnoid space: skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space and dura.
  • On passing through the dura, there is often a slight “click” or “pop” sensation, which indicates the needle is in the subarachnoidspace.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic reaction is not carried by non-microsomal enzymes?
questions.solution:
Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes.

Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes:

  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: Preiser disease is:

choices.text: Traumatic avascular necrosis of the scaphoid
Atraumatic avascular necrosis of the scaphoid

questions.solution:
• Preiser disease is the atraumatic avascular necrosis of scaphoid (osteonecrosis).
  • Its main presentation is wrist pain.
  • Investigations include plain radiographs, CT and MRI.
  • If non-operative methods do not relieve its symptoms, then revascularization techniques must be used.
  • If there is significant collapse of scaphoid and radioscaphoid arthrosis, then scaphoid excision with capitate-lunate-triquetrum-hamate fusion or with proximal row carpectomy can be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about secretin?
questions.solution:
• Secretin is secreted by S cells that are located deep in the glands of the mucosa of the upper portion of the small intes­tine.
  • The secretion of secretin is increased by the products of protein digestion and by acid bathing the mucosa of the upper small intestine.
  • Functions:
    • Increases the secretion of bicarbonate by the duct cells of the pancreas and biliary tract.
    • Augments the action of CCK in producing pancreatic secretion of diges­tive enzymes.
    • Decreases gastric acid secretion and may cause contraction of the pyloric sphincter.
    • Stimulates insulin and inhibits glucagon secretion.

questions.text: Factor X deficiency is associated with which of the following types of amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Vascular amyloidosis causes vascular fragility that may lead to bleeding, sometimes massive, that can occur spontaneously or following seemingly trivial trauma.

In some cases , AL amyloid binds and inactivates factor X, a critical coagulation factor, leading to a life-threatening bleeding disorder.

The clinical manifestations of amyloidosis include:

  • Nephrotic syndrome, eventually renal failure
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Coagulation factor x deficiency (in AL amyloid)
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Macroglossia
  • Purpura
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: Blood brain barrier is absent at
questions.solution:
Area postrema lacks a normal blood brain barrier.

Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are structures in the brain that are characterized by their extensive vasculature and lack of a normal blood brain barrier (BBB).

CVOs can be classified as either sensory or secretory organs.

 The sensory organs include

  • Area postrema (AP)
  • The subforniceal organ (SFO)
  • Vascular organ of lamina terminalis

The secretory organs include Subcommissural organ (SCO)

  • The posterior pituitary
  • The pineal gland
  • The median eminence and the intermediate lobe of the pituitary gland

The lack of a blood brain barrier allows the CVOs to act as an alternative route for peptides and hormones in the neural tissue to the peripheral blood stream, while still protecting it from toxic substances.

questions.text: Banana sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The banana sign is seen in spina bifida.
  • Spina bifida is a type of open neural tube defect and is commonly associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation.

Spina bifida is characterised by:

  • A cleft in the vertebral column
  • With a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

Myelomeningocele (spina bifida) is the most common open neural tube disorder.

Banana sign:

  • It seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II is the banana sign.There is herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem with a curved shape of a banana.

In the image given below, the cerebellum (arrows)  is stretched around the brainstem (B) with effacement of the cisterna magna.

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone that loses convexity, becoming concave or linear at ultrasonography and can be found during the first six months of gestation.

Axial US image of an 18-week old foetus with spina bifida, at the level of Choroid plexus showing the characteristic lemon sign.

questions.text: The first stage in the development of the eye constitutes the formation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Important stages during the development of the eye:

  • The first stage in the development of the eye is the formation of the optic sulcus in the region of the neural plate.
  • As the optic sulcus deepens the wall of the prosencephalon overlying the sulcus bulges outwards to form the optic vesicle.
  • The proximal part of the optic vesicle becomes constricted and elongated to form the optic Stalk.
  • Meanwhile, the surface ectoderm in relation with the optic vesicle becomes thickened to form the lens placode. The lens placode then sinks below the surface to form the lens pit, the ends of which come closer to form the lens vesicle.
  • While the lens vesicle is forming, the optic vesicle becomes converted into a double layered optic cup, due to the differential growth of the wall of the vesicle.
  • Further differentiation and mechanical rearrangement of cells in and around the optic cup gives rise to the fully developed eye.

questions.text: TP53 protein is a
questions.solution:
TP53 is a DNA- binding transcription factor.

p53:

Normally a very unstable protein, p53 is a DNA-binding transcription factor, one of a family of related proteins (i.e. p53, p63, and p73) that is somehow stabilized in response to DNA damage, perhaps by direct p53-DNA interactions.  The tumour suppressor p53 is a protein with apparent molecular weight of 53 kDa.

P53 plays a key role in both G1 and G2 checkpoint control. Increased levels of p53 activate transcription of an ensemble of genes that collectively serve to delay transit through the cycle.

If DNA damage is too extensive to repair, the affected cells undergo apoptosis in a p53-dependent fashion. Cells lacking functional p53 fail to undergo apoptosis in response to high levels of radiation or DNA-active chemotherapeutic agents.

p53 is one of the most frequently mutated genes in human cancers

questions.text: Apple peel deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Apple peel deformity,also known as Christmas tree Deformity is seen in type IIIb jejunoileal atresia where there is a large mesenteric gap between atretic segments and the distal loop gets retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.

Types of jejunoileal atresia:

  • Type I - A mucosal web or diaphragm.
  • Type II - An atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery.
  • Type IIIa - Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap.
  • Type IIIb - An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap, in which the distal bowel receives a retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.

 This tenuous blood supply has implications for anastomotic failures and a potential for ischemic necrosis of volvulus. Hence, many of these infants with this type of atresia are born with reduced intestinal length.

  • Type IV - Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A young man aged 30 years presents with difficulty in vision in the left eye for the last 10 days. He is immunocompetent, a farmer by occupation comes from a rural community and gives a history of trauma to his left eye with vegetative matter 10-15 days back. On examinations, there is an ulcerative lesion in the cornea, whose base has raised soft creamy infiltrate. The ulcer margin is feathery and hyphae. Branching septate hyphae were noted. There are a few satellite lesions also. Corneal scraping shows sickle-shaped macroconidia. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fusarium is the causative agent of the above condition.

  • The above clinical history is suggestive of mycotic keratitis, which is an invasive infection of the cornea usually following corneal trauma.
  • The causative agents of mycotic keratitis include many saprophytic fungi such as Aspergillus species, Fusarium, Curvularia, Alternaria, Acremonium, and Candida albicans.
  • However, in the above question, the causative agent is fusarium due to the presence of sickle-shaped macroconidia.
  • Fusarium is a hyaline filamentous fungi and may cause a range of opportunistic infections in humans.
  • In humans with normal immune systems, fusarial infections may occur in the nails (onychomycosis) and in the cornea (keratomycosis or mycotic keratitis).

questions.text: A pregnant woman is found to have an amniotic fluid index of 26 cm. This condition is associated which of the following?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index of more than 24 cm is said to indicate hydramnios or polyhydramnios.

Hydramnios is often a component of hydrops fetalis.

All other conditions are associated with oligohydramnios where the AFI (amniotic fluid index) is less than or equal to 5 cm.

questions.text: Physical dependence is absent in patients using:
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a serotogenic hallucinogen. Hallucinogen-related abuse doesn’t have physical dependence symptoms even after repeated abuse. Tolerance can develop with closely spaced repeated use.

Physical dependence can be developed to caffeine. Symptoms of caffeine withdrawal include headaches, fatigue, drowsiness, depressed mood, etc.

Alcohol has well-established physical dependence and a withdrawal syndrome which is characterized by symptoms like tremors, insomnia, anxiety, increased body temperature and heart rate, on abstinence.

Heroin is an opioid compound and has a withdrawal syndrome and this is evidence for physical dependence. It is characterized by behavioural or psychological changes like dysphoria, psychomotor agitation, impaired judgment, etc. and also by pupillary constriction with drowsiness and slurred speech.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of skin?

choices.text: The epidermis is composed of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium
Stratum lucidum is present between stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum
Stratum spinosum is also called prickle layer
Melanocytes are present in stratum spinosum

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the structure of the skin is stratum spinosum also called the prickle cell layer.

Stratum spinosum of the skin consists of intercellular attachments, also called desmosomes, which appear like spines on microscopy, hence the name prickle layer or spinous layer. Desmosomes connect keratinocytes in the epidermis of the skin.

The skin is the largest organ in the body and consists of the epidermis and dermis. The epidermis is derived from ectoderm whereas the dermis is derived from mesoderm. The dermal collagens are types I and III while the basement membrane collagen is type IV collagen.

The epidermis is composed of keratinized, stratified squamous epithelium. Depending on the number of layers of the epidermis, either thin skin or thick skin may be seen. 

Thin skin refers to the skin that has four layers of the epidermis, which are, from deep to superficial:

  1. Stratum basale
  2. Stratum spinosum
  3. Stratum granulosum
  4. Stratum corneum. 

Thick skin is found only on the palms and soles. It has a fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, which is located between the stratum corneum and the stratum granulosum.

The malpighian layer of the epidermis includes both stratum basale and stratum spinosum as a unit.

The epidermis is predominantly made up of keratinocytes. Melanocytes and Merkel cells are present in the stratum basale, and langerhans cells are present in the stratum spinosum.

Mnemonic for epidermal layers (superficial to deep): Come Let's Get Some Beer (Corneum, Lucidum, Granulosum, Spinosum, and Basale).

The following image shows the histology and illustration of layers of epidermis:

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: The Resident asks you to perform Allen's test in a patient before cannulating the Radial Artery. This is because Allen’s test is mainly used for _________

choices.text: Assessment of ulnar collateral blood flow
Assessment of radial collateral blood flow

questions.solution:
Allen's Test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded and the patient is asked to make a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the colour of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, the studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text: In the liver, glycogen phosphorylase is inhibited by
questions.solution:
Increased levels of glucose 6 phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase in the liver.

Glycogen phosphorylase regulation:

  • Regulation of Glycogen phosphorylase is different in liver & muscle
    • In the liver, the role of glycogen is to provide free glucose for export to maintain the blood concentration of glucose
    • In muscle, the role of glycogen is to provide a source of glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis in response to the need for ATP for muscle contraction
  • Hence increased glucose 6 phosphate acts as an allosteric inhibitor of glycogen phosphorylase
  • In both tissues, the enzyme is
    • activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase (to yield phosphorylase a)
    • inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by phosphoprotein phosphatase (to yield phosphorylase b)
  • There is instantaneous overriding of this hormonal control. Active phosphorylase a in both tissues is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate
  • In the liver, free glucose is also an inhibitor, but it is not the case in muscle
  • Muscle phosphorylase differs from the liver isoenzyme in having a binding site for 5′ AMP, which acts as an allosteric activator of the (inactive) dephosphorylated b-form of the enzyme.
  • 5′ AMP acts as a potent signal of the energy state of the muscle cell; it is formed as the concentration of ADP begins to increase.
  • cAMP activates glycogen phosphorylase. At the same time, glycogenolysis in liver can be cAMP-Independent which is mediated by Ca2+/calmodulin-sensitive phosphorylase kinase.

So Glucose 6 phosphate , ATP and glucose are inhibitors of liver glycogen phosphorylase.

AMP, Phosphorylase kinase and calcium are activators of glycogen phosphorylase.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman visits a routine health check-up. Her doctor says that she has elevated blood pressure after checking her BP twice. Which of the following is true regarding the above

choices.text: Her BP is < 140 / 90 mmHg and she has to start anti hypertensive medications
Her BP is < 130 / 80 mm Hg and lifestyle modification should be advised
Her BP is > 130 / 90 mm Hg and lifestyle modification should be advised
Her BP is > 130 / 80 mm Hg and she has to start anti hypertensive medications

questions.solution:
According to the latest ACC guidelines on hypertension, elevated blood pressure means systolic BP 120 -129 mmHg and diastolic BP < 80 mm Hg.

Hence in the above question, the lady should have a BP < 130 /80 mmHg.

For elevated hypertension, anti-hypertensive medications are not required.

Only lifestyle modification and dietary advise is given.

questions.text: A family where all of its members play a part in its management is termed as a:
questions.solution:
• A family where all of its members play a part in its management is called a communal family.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Lethal triad in patients of shock undergoing fluid resuscitation includes all except
questions.solution:
The triad of acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy is common in resuscitated patients who are bleeding or in shock from various factors.

Pathophysiology:

Acidosis:

Inadequate tissue perfu­sion results in acidosis caused by lactate production.

Hypothermia:

In the shock state, the delivery of nutrients to the cells is thought to be inad­equate, so adenosine triphosphate (ATP) production decreases.

The human body relies on ATP production to maintain homeo­static temperatures.

ATP is the source of heat in all homeothermic (warm-blooded) animals.

Thus, if ATP production is inadequate to maintain body temperature, the body will trend toward the ambient temperature. For most human patients, this is 22° C (72° F), the temperature inside typical hospitals.

Coagulopathy:

The resulting hypothermia then affects the efficiency of enzymes, which work best at 37° C.  Coagulation cascade depends on enzymes that are affected by hypothermia. 

If enzymes are not functioning optimally because of hypothermia, coagulopathy worsens, which, in surgical patients, can contribute to uncontrolled bleeding from injuries or the surgery itself. Further bleeding continues to fuel the triad.

The optimal method to break the “vicious circle of death” is to stop the bleeding and the causes of hypothermia.

In most typical scenarios, hypothermia is not spontaneous from isch­emia but is induced because of use of room temperature fluid or cold blood products.

questions.text: Bleuler introduced the term ‘schizophrenia’ in 1911. The four primary symptoms of this described by him did not include:
questions.solution:

  • Eugen Bleuler introduced the term ‘schizophrenia’ in 1911.

questions.text: Venturi meter is used in _________
questions.solution:
• Venturi meter is used in slow sand filter to measure the resistance of the sand filter bed which is known as ‘loss of head’.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the microanatomy of the human cell?

choices.text: The lipid of the cell membrane mostly comprises of glycolipids
The plasma membrane and the cytoplasm of the cell together constitutes the protoplasm
Vacuoplasm is the cytoplasm that is present within the channels of the endoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
• The presence of the Endoplasmic Reticulum divides the cytoplasm into two components, one within the channels and one outside them.
  • The cytoplasm within the channels is called the vacuoplasm, and that outside the channels is the hyaloplasm or cytosol.

Other options:

  • Option a:  A cell is bounded by a cell membrane (or plasma membrane), which is made up of lipids and proteins. The lipid molecules predominantly includes phospholipids (not glycolipids).
  • Option b: The protoplasm consists of a central, denser, part called the nucleus; and an outer less dense part called the cytoplasm.

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

The image below is of a schematic to approach to the diagnosis of neonatal jaundice:

questions.text: During the investigation of hydronephrosis, isotope renogram is useful mainly in
questions.solution:
Radioisotope scanning is used to obtain information about function in individual renal units.

A 99mTc-DTPA scan is particularly useful to prove that collecting system dilatation is caused by obstruction. In obstruction, radioactivity will remain in the kidney even if urine ﬂow is stimulated by administration of a diuretic like frusemide (furosemide).

questions.text: All of the following are features of Crohn’s disease except
questions.solution:
• Crohn’s disease is usually rectal sparing though it can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus.
  • Pseudo polyps occur in both Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative colitis.
  • Crohn’s disease is an IBD characterized by transmural inflammation.
  • It is a segmental disease with skip lesions, showing a “cobblestone” appearance on endoscopy.
  • Perianal disease and aphthous ulcers may be seen.
  • The radiographic “string sign” represents long areas of circumferential inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in long segments of luminal narrowing. The segmental nature of CD results in wide gaps of normal or dilated bowel between involved segments.
  • “Lead pipe” appearance is seen in UC which is a continuous disease.
Ulcerative Colitis Crohn’s Disease

Gross

  • Starts from rectum and extends proximally to involve all or part of the colon
  • MC site – rectum
  • Continuous disease
  • Backwash ileitis +
  • In long-standing disease, pseudopolyps +

Gross

  • Can affect any part of GI from mouth to anus.
  • Rectal sparing
  • MC site – terminal ileum
  • Segmental with skip lesions
  • Perianal disease + (fistulas, fissures, abscesses and anal stenosis)
  • As in UC, pseudopolyps
    can form in CD

Microscopic

  • Mucosal involvement
  • Cryptitis and crypt abscesses, collar button ulcers and loss of haustrations
  • Pseudopolyps, adenomatous or carcinomatous polyps
  • ANCA positivity   

Microscopic

  • Transmural involvement
  • Ulceration, granuloma, submucosal lymphoid aggregates
  • Deep fissures penetrating bowel wall and fistulas
  • ASCA positivity

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding communicability with reference to malarial parasite?

choices.text: The gametocytes appear in blood 4-5 days after appearance of first asexual form in P. vivax
The gametocytes appear in blood 10-12 days after appearance of first asexual form in P. falciparum
The number of gametocytes increases in blood with time
The number of gametocytes may exceed 100 per cu.mm of blood

questions.solution:
'Malaria is communicable as long as mature, viable gametocytes exist in the circulating blood in sufficient density to infect vector mosquitoes.'

  • RG interval (Ringform – Gametocyte interval - time interval between appearance of ringform & gametocyte): In vivax infections, - 4-5 days, in falciparum infections - 10-12 days.
  • In P. falciparum, sine the RBC cycle takes place in the vessels of internal organs, hence gametocyte takes time to come to the peripheral blood.
    • Gametocytes are numerous during early stages (may exceed 1,000 per cubic mm of blood) and do not increase in blood with time.

questions.solution:

questions.text: The space of Disse consists of all of the following except
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Browicz cells, are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These are present in the lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse).

The space of Disse:

  • The perisinusoidal space (or space of Disse) is a location in the liver between hepatocytes and the liver sinusoid.
  • It contains the blood plasma.
  • Microvilli of hepatocytes extend into this space, allowing proteins and other plasma components from the sinusoids to be absorbed by the hepatocytes.
  • Some fat cells may also be present in the space of Disse.
  • The perisinusoidal space also contains hepatic stellate cells (also known as cells of Ito), which store fat or fat soluble vitamins including vitamin A).

questions.text: The most appropriate description of vasomotor reversal of Dale is

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Block of alpha1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha1 followed by block of beta 2
Stimulation of beta1 followed by block of beta 2

questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale:

  • Rapid IV injection of adrenaline in animals
  • Marked increase in both diastolic and systolic pressures: alpha action predominates at higher concentrations of adrenaline
  • Adrenaline concentration near nerve terminals reduces rapidly through uptake and dissipation
  • At lower concentrations, no alpha action is seen; beta 2 action predominates resulting in fall of blood pressure
  • When alpha blocker like phentolamine/prazosin is used prior to the administration of adrenaline; only fall in blood pressure is noticed due to stimulation of primarily beta 2 receptors.

questions.text: Drug that can prevent the cardiac remodeling in patients with chronic heart failure is
questions.solution:
Eplerenone is an aldosterone antagonist. Aldosterone antagonists prevent cardiac remodeling. It inhibits the direct deleterious effects of aldosterone on cardiac remodeling and also benefits indirectly by its action on extracellular volume and cardiac workload.

Treatment of CHF:

  • Relief of congestive symptoms and restoration of cardiac performance
    • Inotropic drugs (digoxin, dobutamine, amrinone)
    • Diuretics (Furosemide, Thiazides)
    • RAAS inhibitors (ACE inhibitors/ ARBs)
    • Vasodilators-  (hydralazine, nitrate, nitroprusside)
    • Beta blockers (metoprolol, carvedilol)
  • Reversal of disease progression - These drugs prevent ventricular remodelling
    • ACE inhibitors / ARBS
    • Beta blockers
    • Aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone, eplerenone)
    • Combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate has also shown to reduce mortality in CHF.

questions.text: DSM-5 criteria for depression states that symptoms have to be present for at least ______ weeks
questions.solution:
• DSM-5 criteria for depression states that symptoms have to be present for at least 2 weeks. This was also the same in the DSM-IV criteria.
  • According to the DM-5, a major depressive episode requires a minimum duration of at least 2 weeks of major symptoms like depressed mood for most of the day, nearly every day.
  • The criteria further states that four additional (or more) symptoms should accompany the depressed mood for the same minimum of 2 weeks. These symptoms can be changes in appetite/weight, changes in sleep, changes in level of motor activity and suicidal ideation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is evident from the histological section of the skin shown below?
questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of nucleated cells in the stratum corneum, which indicates parakeratosis. Note that normally, the cells of stratum corneum are devoid of nucleus.

  • Parakeratosis is defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within the horny cell layer or stratum corneum.
  • It represents a disorder of keratinization, and is usually associated with an absence or reduction in thickness of the granular cell layer.
  • The histological feature of parakeratosis is commonly seen in many different forms of inflammatory dermatosis, and is closely associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.

Parakeratosis is commonly seen in

  • Psoriasis
  • Subacute eczematous reactions
  • Pityriasis lichenoides
  • Actinic keratoses
  • Bowen disease

questions.text: All of the following statements are true with regards to the bony orbit, except ____

choices.text: Most of the floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxilla
The floor of the orbit forms the roof of the maxillary sinus
The roof of the orbit is formed by the orbital plate of frontal bone and greater wing of sphenoid
The lamina papyracea of the ethmoid bone forms the medial wall of the orbit

questions.solution:
The bony orbits are the skeletal cavities which are located on either side of the root of the nose, that serve as sockets for the eyes and associated tissues.

Roof of the orbit:

  • The roof of the orbit is formed mainly by the thin orbital plate of the frontal bone, and the lesser wing of sphenoid.
  • It separates the orbital contents from the brain in the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The optic canal lies between the roots of the lesser wing and is bounded medially by the body of the sphenoid.

Medial wall of the orbit:

  • It is mainly formed by the orbital plate (lamina papyracea) of the ethmoid bone. The lamina papyracea covers the middle and posterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • Other structures forming the medial wall include: Frontal process of maxilla, lacrimal bone, and body of sphenoid.

Floor of the orbit:

  • The orbital surface of the body of the maxilla forms most of the floor of the orbit. It articulates with the zygomatic bone anterolaterally and the small triangular orbital process of the palatine bone posteromedially.
  • The floor is thin and forms the roof of the maxillary sinus.
  • It is separated from the lateral wall by the inferior orbital fissure
  • The palatine bones are placed posteriorly in the nasal cavity, and contribute to the floor of the orbit and to the inferior orbital fissures, among others.

Lateral wall of the orbit:

  • It is formed by the orbital surface of the greater wing of the sphenoid posteriorly and the frontal process of the zygomatic bone anteriorly.
    • The bones meet at the sphenozygomatic suture.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given barium swallow image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and a characteristic bird-beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

In achalasia cardia, the lower esophagral spinchter (LES) is hypertensive and fails to relax appropriately in response to swallowing. Sphincter spasm and delayed emptying through LES are also seen. Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of esophageal achalasia.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important property of synthetic mesh in reconstructive pelvic surgery?

choices.text: Ability to resist tissue in growth

questions.solution:
The pore size is the most important property of synthetic mesh. Pore size is also the basis of tissue ingrowth, angiogenesis, flexibility and strength.

Bacteria generally measure less than 1 micrometer, granulocytes and macrophages are more than 10 micrometers.

Thus, a mesh with pore size less than 10 micrometer will allow bacteria but not macrophage infiltration and thereby predispose to infection.

Type I mesh has the lowest rate of infection compared with types II, III.

Meshes are either monofilament or multifilament and monofilament mesh is the best choice for reconstructive pelvic surgery.

Synthetic mesh is classified as type I through IV, based on the pore size.

questions.text: The degrees of freedom for a contingency table with 3 rows and 6 columns is _______
questions.solution:
In a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1)(c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

The above contingency table has 3 rows and 6 columns

In this scenario, dof = (3 – 1) (6 – 1) = 10

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: The following graph shows the recording of cervical dilatation against time. All of the following statements are true regarding the graph except:

choices.text: The preparatory division includes A,D in the graph
The dilatational division occupies the phase of E in the graph
In nulliparas the minimum normal rate of progression of phase B in the graph is 1.5 cm/hour
Protraction and arrest disorders are problems associated with phase B of the graph

questions.solution:
The phase B in the above graph corresponds to the active phase of labor, and in nulliparas, the minimum normal rate of progression is 1.2 cm/hour.

In the above graph:

  • A corresponds to latent phase of labor
  • B corresponds to active phase of labor
  • C corresponds to second stage of labor
  • D corresponds to acceleration phase
  • E corresponds to phase of maximum slope
  • F corresponds to deceleration phase

A scientific approach by Friedman (1954) described a characteristic sigmoid pattern for labor by graphing cervical dilatation against time.

questions.text: According to the Indian National Health Policy of 2017, one of the specific, quantitative goals of impact is to reduce the stillbirth rate to _________ by 2025
questions.solution:
According to the Indian National Health Policy of 2017, one of the specific, quantitative goals of impact is to reduce neo-natal mortality to 16 and still birth rate to “single digit” by 2025.

National Health Policy, 2017:

The draft of the policy from 2015 was passed by the government in 2017 and is called the National Health Policy, 2017.

Specific quantitative goals and objectives:

   These can be divided into three broad components

  1. Health Status and Programme Impact:
    • Increase life expectancy at birth from 67.5 to 70 by 2025
    • Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 28 by 2019
    • Reduce Neonatal Mortality to 16 and still birth rate to single digit by 2025
    • Reduce Maternal Mortality Ratio(MMR) from current levels to 100 by 2020
    • Achieve elimination of lymphatic filariasis by 2017

  2. Health Systems Performance:

    • Increase utilization of public health facilities by 50% from current levels by 2025
    • Antenatal care coverage to be sustained above 90%
    • More than 90% of the newborn are fully immunized by one year of age by 2025.
    • Access to safe water and sanitation to all by 2020 (Swachh Bharat Mission)
  3. Health Systems Financing:
    • Increase health expenditure to 2.5% of GDP by 2025

    • Increase State sector health spending to > 8% of their budget by 2020.

 

Priority actions to improve environment for health

  • Swachh Bharat Abhiyan
  • Balanced healthy diets and regular exercise
  • Addressing tobacco, alcohol and substance abuse
  • Yatri Suraksha to reduce death due to accidents
  • Nirbhaya Nari for action against gender violence
  • Reduced stress and improved safety in work places
  • Reducing indoor and outdoor air pollution

Other provisions in this policy include the NEET exam for UG, increased thrust in HIV-centered communities for treatment and diagnosis, establishment of nursing schools in every district and food safety.

questions.text: Zuska’s disease refers to

choices.text: Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of breast
Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages

questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses.

Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition.

Treatment: Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Option a: Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast is referred to as Mondor’s disease.

Option b: Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages is referred to as Tietze’s syndrome.

Option d: Stewart Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphoedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: A boy presents with breathlessness to the hospital. He gives a history of leg pain over the calf for a few days, for which he sought massaging from his mother, after which he developed breathlessness. Which of the following findings on the ECG would suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism for this patient?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis leading to pulmonary embolism.

The specific abnormality in ECG seen in pulmonary embolism is

The S1 Q3 T3 sign:

  • S wave in lead I
  • Q wave in lead III
  • Inverted T wave in lead III

S1Q3T3 is highly specific but not sensitive (meaning it is not always present).

Instead, the most common abnormality in pulmonary embolism is right ventricular (RV) strain and ischemia, which is depicted on an ECG as T-wave inversions in leads V1-V4.

questions.text: The earliest detectable congenital malformations by USG is ______
questions.solution: Anencephaly, holoprosencephaly, and ventral wall defects have very high rate of detection in first trimester. The remaining of the anomalies can be detected in second trimester.

questions.text: CATCH-22 complex doesn’t include:
questions.solution:
• CATCH-22 complex includes cardiac anomalies, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate and hypocalcaemia.
  • CATCH-22 is an acronym used to represent the conditions that are associated with deletion that occurs in regions of the chromosome 22q11.2.
  • This complex is associated with DiGeorge’s syndrome or Shprintzen (velocardiofacial) syndrome.
  • Cardiac anomalies seen are usually conotruncal defects like tetralogy of Fallot, subarterial VSD, etc and branchial arch defects like right aortic arch, coarctation of aorta, etc.

questions.solution:
Semi critical items are those that come in contact with mucous membranes or minor skin breaches (non-intact skin) and they need high level of disinfection.

Spaulding classification is used to classify the devices used on the patient, which determines the type of method selected for disinfection or sterilization.

  • The three categories of the devices are critical, semi critical, or noncritical
  • The system also established three levels of germicidal activity for disinfection (high, intermediate, and low).

questions.text: A physician recorded diastolic BP in 125 women aged 18 – 60 years and found the mean to be 70 mmHg with standard deviation of 10mmHg. Using z-scores, find the 5th percentile value.
questions.solution:
The z value for the 5th percentile is -1.645.

Using the formula for z scores, z = (X- µ)/σ, we get X = zσ + µ.

In this scenario, X = (-1.645 x 10) + 70 = -16.45 + 70 = 53.55 = 53.6.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was rapidly administered a muscle relaxant, which resulted in erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, associated with a fall in arterial pressure and an increase in heart rate were noted. Which of the following is most commonly implicated?
questions.solution:
The above clinical signs and symptoms caused by the rapid administration of muscle relaxant are attributed to histamine release. The side effect of histamine release is most often noted following the administration of the benzylisoquinoline class of muscle relaxants, mainly by d-tubocurarine.

Clinical features associated with histamine release include erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, as well as a brief decrease in arterial pressure with a slight to moderate increase in heart rate. The serosal mast cells, located near the blood vessels and nerves in the skin and connective tissue are principally involved in the degranulation process. 

The following table shows autonomic effects of various neuromuscular blocking drugs:

Drug Type Autonomic Ganglia Cardiac Muscarinic Receptors Histamine Release
Depolarizing
Substance
Succinylcholine  Stimulates  Stimulates  Less
Benzyl-isoquinolinium Compounds
d-Tubocurarine
(dTc)		  Blocks  No effect  Moderate
Mivacurium  No effect  No effect  Less
Atracurium  No effect  No effect  Less
Cisatracurium  No effect  No effect  None
Steroidal Compounds
Vecuronium  No effect  No effect  None
Rocuronium  No effect  Weak blockage  None
Pancuronium  No effect  Moderate blockage  None


From the above table, it is evident that d-tubocurarine is the most potent histamine releaser. Also, dTc causes hypotension both by histamine release and ganglion blockade.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., aspirin), in addition to anti-histamines, help prevent the development of hypotension with the administration of d-Tubocurarine. Slower injection rates have been shown to reduce the incidence of this side effect.

questions.text: According to Denis’ concept, how many columns are present in the vertebral column?
questions.solution:
• Denis developed the three-column vertebral model based on his review of works of other authors.
  • His goal was to highlight the injury patterns resulting from specific injury mechanisms.

He introduced the abstract concept of the ‘middle column’ which is actually the posterior half of the vertebral body, the posterior half of the intervertebral disc and the posterior longitudinal ligament.
