questions.text: All are true about dystrophic calcification except:
questions.solution:
Dystrophic calcification is seen in necrosed tissue.

Dystrophic calcification:

  • It is encountered in areas of necrosis, whether they area of coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive type and in foci of enzymatic necrosis of fat.
  • Calcification is almost always present in the atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves, further hampering their function
  • Calcium salts appear macroscopically as fine, white granules or clumps, often felt as gritty deposits
  • Tuberculous lymph nodes can be affected by this
  • Although dystrophic calcification may simply be a telltale sign of previous cell injury, it is often a cause of organ dysfunction
  • Serum calcium is normal in dystrophic calcification

questions.text: Maternal death is defined as when a woman dies during pregnancy or at the time of delivery or after delivery up to _________ weeks
questions.solution: • Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

questions.text: In the three-glass urine test, threads are present in first glass only. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The "three-glass urine test" is valuable in the diagnosis of chronic prostatitis. If the first glass with initially voided urine contains prostatic threads, prostatitis is present.

Rectal examination of the prostate may be normal or may show a soft, boggy, and tender prostate. Examination of the prostatic fluid obtained by prostatic massage should show pus cells and bacteria.

questions.text: A serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated to determine whether ascites is secondary to portal hypertension or not. Which of the following conditions does not have high serum ascites albumin gradient (>1.1g/dL)?
questions.solution:
Tubercular peritonitis has low serum ascites albumin gradient.

The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

The SAAG is calculated by measuring the albumin concentration of serum and ascitic fluid specimens and subtracting the ascitic fluid value from the serum value. 

If the SAAG is 1.1 g/dL or more, the patient has portal hypertension; a SAAG of less than 1.1 g/dL is consistent with the absence of portal hypertension.

High gradient (≥1.1 g/dl) 

  • Cirrhosis
  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Cardiac failure
  • Massive liver metastases
  • Fulminant hepatic failure
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Myxedema

Low gradient (<1.1 g/dl)

  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis 
  • Tuberculous peritonitis
  • Pancreatic ascites
  • Biliary ascites
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Postoperative lymphatic leak
  • Serositis in connective tissue diseases

questions.text: Austin’s classification for anatomical defects in ossicular chain is based on
questions.solution:
Austin’s classification: Based on presence or absence of malleus handle (M) and stapes Suprastructure (S) assuming incus is absent in all cases.

  • Type A: M+ S+ Both handle of malleus and stapes suprastructure are present. Reconstruction is by PORP.
  • Type B: M+ S- Handle of malleus is present but stapes suprastructure is absent. Reconstruction is by TORP.
  • Type C: M- S+ Only stapes Suprastructure is present. Reconstruction is by PORP.
    • Type D: M- S- All ossicles are missing. Reconstruction is by TORP.

questions.text: Sigma factor is a component of
questions.solution:
• RNA polymerase holoenzyme(ββ’α2ωσ) = Core enzyme (ββ’α2ω) + σ factor (sigma)
  • In prokaryotes, σ factor is needed for the identification of prokaryotes
  • σ subunit enables the core enzyme to recognize and bind the promoter region to form the preinitiation complex (PIC)
  • There are multiple, distinct σ factor encoding genes in all bacterial species
  • Sigma factors have a dual role in the process of promoter recognition; σ-association with core RNA polymerase decreases its affinity for non-promoter DNA while simultaneously increasing holoenzyme affinity for promoter DNA.
  • The appearance of different σ -factors and their association with core RNA polymerase to form novel holoenzyme forms E σ 1, E σ 2 and so on can be correlated temporally with various programs of gene expression in prokaryotic systems such as sporulation, growth in various poor nutrient sources and the response to heat shock.
  • In eukaryotes, TATA box binding domain of TFIID recognises the promoter

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anaesthetic is mainly associated with hepatotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Halothane is mainly known to be associated with complications such as hepatotoxicity.

Halothane causes  impaired hepatic perfusion, hepatocyte hypoxia, benign postoperative intrahepatic cholestasis, and halothane hepatitis.

Patients exposed to multiple doses of halothane at short intervals, middle-aged obese women, and persons with a familial predisposition to halothane toxicity or a personal history of toxicity are considered to be at increased risk.

Halothane hepatitis is the result of an immune response to hepatic proteins that are trifluoroacetylated as a consequence of halothane metabolism. This leads to centrilobular necrosis of the liver and results in clinical manifestations. It may also be associated with jaundice and encephalopathy.

Halothane is contraindicated in patients with unexplained liver dysfunction following previous anaesthetic exposure.

questions.text: The only DNA polymerase with 5’→3’ exonuclease activity in prokaryotes is:
questions.solution:
• The 5'→3' exonuclease activity of DNA pol I allows the polymerase, moving 5'→3', to hydrolytically remove one or more nucleotides at a time from the 5' end of the 20 to 30 nucleotide–long RNA primer.
  • In contrast, the 3'→5' exonuclease activity of DNA pol I, as well as DNA pol II and III, allows these polymerases, moving 3'→5', to hydrolytically remove one misplaced nucleotide at a time from the 3' end of a growing DNA strand, increasing the fidelity of replication such that newly replicated DNA has one error per 107 nucleotides.

DNA polymerases:

DNA polymerase Description
I

Made up of a single subunit

DNA Polymerisation: 5'→3' polymerase activity

Proofreading: 3'→5' exonuclease activity

Removal of RNA primer, DNA repair: 5'→3' exonuclease activity
II

Made up of 7 subunits

Proof reading & repair; error prone polymerase.

5'→3' polymerase & 3'→5' exonuclease activity
III

Major enzyme of replication

Biggest enzyme with >10 subunits

Highly Processive enzyme with high polymerisation rate

5'→3' polymerase & 3'→5' exonuclease activity

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an orthopedic emergency?

choices.text: Compartment syndrome of the forearm following supracondylar humerus fracture in a child
Neck of femur fracture in a young adult presenting an hour after injury
Open book pelvis injury in a patient with hypotension
Closed humeral shaft fracture with wrist drop

questions.solution:
• The radial nerve is most commonly injured with fractures of the humeral shaft causing wrist drop. Recovery rates of wrist drop in closed humeral fractures (low-energy injuries) is almost 100% and it is treated in the usual non-operative manner. The radial nerve injuries here are usually neuropraxia.
  • Neck of femur fracture in a young adult predisposes to avascular necrosis and thus it is an orthopedic emergency.
  • Compartment syndrome of the forearm after supracondylar humeral fracture and open book pelvis injuries in a hypotensive patient are life-threatening injuries and need to be treated immediately.

questions.text: The following comes under what classification of breech presentation?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a footling breech, which is an incomplete breech with one or more feet below the breech.

The categories of breech presentation are:

  • Frank breech: the lower extremities are flexed at the hips and extended at the knees and thus the feet lie in close proximity to head.
  • Complete breech: the lower extremities are flexed at the hips and one or both knees are flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: one or both hips are not flexed and one or both feet or knees lie below the breech such that a foot or a knee is the lowermost in the birth canal.

questions.text: The following are true regarding recurrent miscarriages except

choices.text: Infections are often the main reason of miscarriages
There is a role for various polymorphisms of gene expression in miscarriages
Autoimmune or uterine anatomical abnormalities cause second trimester losses
First trimester loss in recurrent miscarriages have a significantly lower incidence of genetic abnormalities than sporadic losses

questions.solution:
Infections seldom cause even sporadic losses. Hence most infections are unlikely to cause recurrent miscarriages.

There are only 3 widely accepted causes of recurrent abortion:

  • Parental chromosomal abnormalities
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Subset of uterine abnormalities

Option b:

Few examples of polymorphisms:

  • Polymorphisms that alter VEGF-A expression
  • Polymorphisms that exaggerate platelet aggregation
  • Polymorphism with a specific type of T1, T2 immune response

Option c:

Genetic factors result in early embryonic losses and autoimmune or uterine anatomical abnormalities cause second trimester losses.

Option d:

First trimester loss in recurrent miscarriages have a significantly lower incidence of genetic abnormalities than sporadic losses of 25% versus 50%.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly associated?
questions.solution:
Inamrinone is a selective PDE-3 inhibitor.

PDE-3 isoenzyme is specific for intracellular degradation of cAMP in heart, blood vessels and bronchial smooth muscles.

It is referred to as inodilator i.e. causes positive inotropy and direct vasodilatation thus reducing both preload and after load.

Inamrinone is indicated for short term management of severe and refractory CHF.

Option a: Theophylline is a non-selective PDE inhibitor indicated in the management of bronchial asthma.

Option b: Sildenafil is a specific PDE-5 inhibitor indicated for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension.

Option d: Roflumilast is a specific PDE-4 inhibitor indicated for the management of COPD.

questions.text: A strain of E. coli isolated from urine is resistant to third generation cephalosporins. The mechanism of development of resistance is:
questions.solution:
• Out of several mechanisms of beta lactam resistance in E.coli, Beta-Lactamase production is the MOST COMMON particularly Extended spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBL).
  • Production of extended-spectrum β-lactamases (ESBLs) is a significant resistance-mechanism that impedes the antimicrobial treatment of infections caused by Enterobacteriaceae.
  • Extended-spectrum β-lactamases (ESBLs; e.g., CTX-M, SHV, TEM) are modified broad-spectrum enzymes that confer resistance to most beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins including third-generation cephalosporins, aztreonam, and (in some instances) fourth-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents are known to cause dissociative anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ketamine produces dissociative anesthesia through antagonistic actions at the phencyclidine (PCP) site of the N -methyl- d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. It functionally “dissociates” the thalamus (which relays sensory impulses from the reticular activating system to the cerebral cortex) from the limbic cortex (which is involved with the awareness of sensation).

  • The anesthetized state caused by ketamine has been termed dissociative anesthesia because patients who receive ketamine alone appear to be in a cataleptic state, in contrast to other states of anesthesia that resemble normal sleep.
  • Patients anesthetized with ketamine have profound analgesia, but they keep their eyes open and maintain many reflexes. The patient has no recall of surgery or anesthesia.

questions.text: Number of criteria needed to make a diagnosis of recurrent attack of acute rheumatic fever is

For all patients with evidence of preceding Group A streptococcal pharyngitis, initial rheumatic fever can be diagnosed when

questions.text: Amongst the following, which is the most common co-morbidity for affective disorders with suicidal behaviour?

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as rape

choices.text: Intercourse with a girl < 18 years of age
Intercourse with wife less than 15 years of age
Intercourse with girl against her will

questions.solution:
A man is said to commit “rape” if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:

  • Against her will
  • Without her consent
  • With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.
  • With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband, and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
  • With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
  • With or without her consent, when she is under sixteen years of age

Explanation: Penetration is sufficient to constitute the sexual intercourse necessary to the offence of rape.

Exception (Recent update): Sexual intercourse by a man with his own wife, the wife not being under 15 years of age, is not rape.

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Anxious parents brought their infant to the pediatric outpatient with complaints of an abnormal increase in the size of his head. Investigations revealed hydrocephalus due to the vein of Galen malformation. Identify the great vein of Galen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The great vein of Galen is marked as '1' in the image given above.

The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus, located along the junction between the falx and the tentorium cerebelli.

Clinical significance:

  • Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM) is the most common form of symptomatic cerebrovascular malformation in neonates and infants.
  • Vein of Galen malformation can result in hydrocephalus, heart failure, or rarely, hemorrhage.
  • There may be the absence of great vein of Galen in some congenital disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following dressing for full-thickness and contaminated burns helps to reduce cell-mediated immunosuppression?
questions.solution:
Silver sulfadiazine and cerium nitrate has been shown in certain instances, to reduce some of the cell-mediated immunosupression that occurs in burns.

Cerium nitrate has also been shown to boost the cell-mediated immunity in patients.

Option A

Silver sulfadiazine gives broad spectrum prophylaxis against bacterial colonization and is particularly effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B

Silver nitrate solution (0.5%) is effective against Pseudomonas colonization but not as effective as silver sulfadiazine cream.

Option C

Mafenide acetate cream is popular especially in the United States but is painful to apply.

questions.text: All are early morphological features of HIV lymphadenopathy except

choices.text: Impingement of germinal centers on interfollicular T cell areas

questions.solution:
Hyalinization of germinal centers is a late feature of HIV lymphadenopathy.

Biopsy specimens from enlarged lymph nodes :

In the early stages of HIV infection reveal:

  • Marked hyperplasia of B cell follicles.
  • The follicles are enlarged and often take on unusual, serpiginous shapes.
  • The mantle zones that surround the follicles are attenuated
  • The germinal centers impinge on interfollicular T cell areas.
  • This hyperplasia of B cells is the morphologic reﬂection of the polyclonal B-cell activation and hypergammaglobulinemia seen in HIV-infected individuals.

Late stages show :

With disease progression,

  • The frenzy of B-cell proliferation subsides and gives way to a pattern of severe lymphoid involution.
  • The lymph nodes are depleted of lymphocytes, and the organized network of follicular dendritic cells is disrupted.
  • Germinal centers may even become hyalinized
  • Viral burden in the nodes is reduced
  • These “burnt-out” lymph nodes are atrophic and small and may harbor numerous opportunistic pathogens, often within macrophages.
  • Because of profound immunosuppression, the inﬂammatory response to infections both in the lymph nodes and at extranodal sites may be sparse or atypical
  • In  the  empty-looking  lymph  nodes  and  in  other  organs, the presence of infectious agents may not be readily  apparent  without  special  stains. 
  • Lymphoid involution is not confined to the nodes
  • In later stages of AIDS, the spleen and thymus also are converted to “wastelands” that are virtually devoid of lymphocytes.

questions.text: These 2 molecules are _______ of each other.
questions.solution:
Mannose and galactose are epimers of glucose. But, galactose is not the epimer of mannose.

Isomers differing as a result of variations in configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, and 4 of glucose are known as epimers. Biologically, the most important epimers of glucose are mannose (epimerized at carbon 2) and galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).

Since D-mannose and D-galactose differ in position of –OH group , at two carbon atoms (2nd and 4th ) , they will be diastereoisomers rather than epimers.

questions.text: In which of the following methods of interval partial salpingectomy is a mesosalpinx opening created?
questions.solution:
In the Parkland method the mesosalpinx is opened.

In the Parkland method, at the midpoint of the fallopian tube, an avascular segment of the mesosalpinx is identified and a hemostat is placed directly beneath the tube.

The selected site should allow a 2 cm excision of tubal segment without incorporating the fimbria.

The hemostat is advanced through the mesosalpinx and the aperture is expanded. A 0 – gauge chromic free tie is used to secure on the distal and another on the proximal fallopian tube

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient came to the OPD with complaints of swelling over the cervical region. On examination, it is found to be painless lymphadenopathy along with the presence of splenomegaly. On HPE examination, the following picture given in the image is seen with the absence of centroblasts. Immunophenotyping shows CD23 negative, CD 19 and CD 20 positive.
Which of the following is false regarding the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical and biopsy picture points to Mantle cell lymphoma, which has its origin from naïve B cells, which are characterised by a lack of somatic hypermutation of the IgH gene (Due to the tumour arising from Naive B Cells).

Mantle cell lymphoma :

  • Tumor cells resemble the normal mantle zone B- cells which surround the germinal centre
  • Seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life
  • Has male predominance
  • Has (11;14) translocation (Option A)
  • IgH locus on – chromosome 14
  • Cyclin D1 locus on – chromosome 11
  • Overexpression of Cyclin D1 is seen (Option B)

Features:

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon – lymphomatoid polyposis (Option D)

Histology :

  • Nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centres to produce a nodular appearance at low power or diffusely efface the node.
  • Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours
  • Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively

Immunophenotyping :

  • CD 5+
  • CD 23 negative
  • CD19 and  CD20 positive
  • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain)
  • The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding alopecia areata is incorrect?

choices.text: It is characterized by the presence of exclamation mark hair
Alopecia universalis means loss of all of the body hair
Ophiasis is a pattern of loss of hair along the back of scalp
Oral corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Intralesional corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice in alopecia areata. 

  • A depot steroid (hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/mL or triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/mL), administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis or by a needleless device, will stimulate hair growth at the site of injection.
  • Oral corticosteroids are used if initial treatment fails.

Other options:

Option A: The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia, which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair, as shown in the image below.

 

Option B: Alopecia totalis means loss of all scalp hair and alopecia universalis means loss of all body hair.

The image below shows alopecia totalis with few eyebrows, eyelashes, and axillary hair, respectively.

 

 

Option C: Ophiasis is a pattern of alopecia areata characterized by the extension of alopecia (loss of hair) along the back of the scalp.

questions.text: A newborn child is HIV + and symptomatic. Which of the following vaccines must not be given?
questions.solution:

NOTE: In India, for Japanese encephalitis, both live attenuated SA-14-14-2 vaccine and inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA 14-14-2 vaccine, (IXIARO® and JEEV®) are available.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism. Her pregnancy test was positive and gestation age was 5 weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate for the management of hyperthyroidism in this patient?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU). It is because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole or methimazole.

Methimazole is associated with teratogenic effects collectively called methimazole embryopathy which include upward-slanted palpebral fissures, arched flared eyebrows, and a small nose with a broad bridge. Choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, and aplasia cutis can be seen. However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of liver failure. It is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy.

Propylthiouracil is an anti-thyroid drug that inhibits the coupling and iodination of thyroid hormones decreasing the production of the hormones. It also has the additional property of inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

The most serious adverse effect of propylthiouracil is agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis usually occurs in the initial weeks or months of therapy. It occurs rapidly and hence periodic monitoring of granulocyte levels is generally ineffective. However, it is reversible on discontinuation of the drug. Therefore, patients who are on these drugs should be instructed to report immediately if they develop a fever or sore throat. They can be treated with recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors. Other side effects include mild urticarial papular rash, joint pain, headache, nausea, skin pigmentation, and loss of hair. 

Note: Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: Superantigen is produced by
questions.solution:
Superantigens are the third variety of biological class of antigens, recently described in last decade. The unique feature of superantigens is that they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen presenting cells (APCs).

Examples of Superantigens

Bacterial superantigens:

  • Staphylococcal toxin: TSST, Exfoliative toxin, Enterotoxins
  • Streptococcal toxin: Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE)-A and C
  • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen-l
  • Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis

Viral: EBV, CMV, Rabies nucleocapsid, HIV encoded nef (negative regulatory factor)

Fungal superantigen: Malassezia furfur

Note: The streptococcal toxins SPE-A, and SPE-C, which are superantigens are produced by streptococcal pyogenes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with reference to the Couinaud's liver segments?

choices.text: It is classified based on the distribution of hepatic arteries in the parenchyma
The left lobe of the liver includes segments I, II, and III
Segment IV corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver
The right lobe of the liver includes segments V, VI, VII, and VIII

questions.solution:
The right lobe of the liver includes Couinaud’s segments V, VI, VII, and VIII.

  • The right anterior sector is formed by segments V and VIII
  • The right posterior sector is formed by segments VI and VII

Other options:

  • Option a: The classification of the liver segments based on the Couinaud’s system is based on the distribution of the portal venous system in the parenchyma.
  • Option b: The left lobe of the liver includes segments II, III (Left lateral sectors) and segment IV (quadrate lobe)
  • Option c: The segment I is represented by the caudate lobe of the liver, whereas segment IV is represented by the quadrate lobe.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

Option a: Electra complex refers to sexual desire of daughter towards her father.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of pain and early morning stiffness in the lower back. The following test was done. In which disease is the following test done?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the modified Schober test. It is done to measure lumbar spine flexion in ankylosing spondylitis.

In this test, the patient stands erect with the heels together, and two points are marked on the spine, as shown in the illustration below: one at the level of the lumbosacral junction (a horizontal line between the two posterosuperior iliac spines) and one 10 cm above this level. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥ 2 cm.

HLA-B27 is strongly linked to AS and it plays a direct role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The clinical features of AS first appear during late adolescence and early adulthood. The patients complain of early morning pain and stiffness in the lower back. The condition improves with activity and returns with inactivity. As the disease progresses, the pain becomes bilateral and persistent. 

On examination, there is restriction of all the movements of the lumbar spine (anterior and lateral flexion, and extension). Other changes which are seen in the spine include obliteration of the lumbar lordosis, accentuated thoracic kyphosis, and restriction of the chest expansion. In advanced spinal disease, there is a high risk of spinal fracture (most often in the cervical region) due to osteoporosis and the spine being rigid. Such a fracture is mostly associated with spinal cord injury. 

Radiography of the lumbosacral region shows squaring of the vertebral bodies, formation of marginal syndesmophytes, and eventual fusion of the vertebral bodies. This is known as bamboo spine appearance, and is shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hybridoma is false?

choices.text: Specific antibody-producing cells are integrated with myeloma cells.
Myeloma cells using salvage pathway grow well in HAT medium.
Aminopterin, a folate antagonist, inhibits de novo pathway.
HGPRTase and thymidylate synthetase are required for salvage pathway.

questions.solution:
The false statement is that myeloma cells using salvage pathway grow well in HAT medium.

Aminopterin is a folate antagonist present in the HAT medium. It inhibits the de novo pathway of nucleotide synthesis. Thus, cells utilise the hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine present in the medium for nucleotide by the salvage pathway. Since myeloma cells cannot use the salvage pathway due to the absence of HGPRTase enzyme, they cannot survive in the HAT medium.

Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of identical antibodies (monoclonal antibodies). Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture. 
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

questions.solution:
The image is that of a transposition flap, which is the most basic design that leaves a graftable donor site.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of DPP-4 inhibitors is
questions.solution:
DPP-4 inhibitors inhibit the degradation of GLP-1 and GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotrophic polypeptide).

GLP-1 and GIP are incretins that are released after meals and stimulate insulin secretion in a glucose dependent manner. Therefore, DPP-4 inhibitors mechanism of action is through glucose dependent insulin release.

questions.text: The nutcracker syndrome refers to the compression of _______

choices.text: Left renal vein between the Inferior vena cava and the superior mesenteric vein
Right renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery
Left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery
Right renal vein between the Inferior vena cava and the superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
• The left renal vein lies anterior to the aorta, and posterior & inferior to the superior mesenteric artery.

Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

Clinical presentation:

  • The most common clinical manifestation of the nutcracker syndrome is intermittent macroscopic haematuria. Repeated episodes of gross haematuria and left flank pain should be present.
  • Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein it may also result in left testicular pain in men or left lower quadrant pain in women.
  • Nausea and vomiting can result due to compression of the splanchnic veins.
  • In some cases it is characterized by left renal vein hypertension secondary to compression, and has been associated with haematuria and varicocele in children.

questions.text:
Identify the type of Mapleson’s circuit shown in the image below.

FG- Fresh gas

P- Patient
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mapleson’s Type B breathing circuit. There is the presence of a corrugated tube, and the fresh gas flow and valve are located near the patient.

Mapleson’s breathing systems are used for delivering oxygen and anesthetic agents and eliminating carbon dioxide during anesthesia. They consist of different components: Fresh gas flow, reservoir bag, breathing tubes, expiratory valve, and patient connection.

There are six types of Mapleson’s circuits denoted by A – F.

Other options:

Option A - In Mapleson type A circuits, the fresh gas flow enters through the opposite end of the circuit near the reservoir bag. They have a spring-loaded pop-off valve located near the patient. It is the most efficient for spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Type C Mapleson circuits are similar to Type B circuits, but they do not have the corrugated tube.

Option D - Type D  circuits have fresh gas flow is near the patient end, and excess gas is vented off at the opposite end of the circuit. It is the most efficient for controlled ventilation.

 

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: Type I statistical errors occur if

choices.text: Null hypothesis is true but rejected
Null hypothesis is true and accepted
Null hypothesis is false but accepted
Null hypothesis is false and rejected

questions.solution:
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true is called as a type I error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors in developing epithelial ovarian cancer except
questions.solution:
Tubal ligation and hysterectomy are each associated with a substantial reduction in risk of ovarian cancer.

Theoretically, any gynecological procedure that precludes irritants from reaching the ovaries via ascension from the lower genital tract might plausibly exert a similar protective effect.

Risk factors for developing epithelial ovarian cancer:

  • Nulliparity
  • Early menarche
  • Late menopause
  • White race
  • Increasing age
  • Family history
  • Personal history of breast cancer
  • Ethnic background (European, Jewish, Icelandic, Hungarian)
  • Postmenopausal hormone therapy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease

questions.text: It is true regarding the normal microbial flora present on the skin and mucous membranes that:

choices.text: It establishes in the body only after the neonatal period
It is absent in the stomach due to acidic pH
It cannot be eradicated by antimicrobial agents
The flora in the small bronchi is similar to that of the trachea

questions.solution:
The normal microbial flora cannot be eradicated by antimicrobial agents. It can only decrease the number of organisms

  • Term “normal microbial flora" denotes the population of microorganisms that inhabit the skin and mucous membranes of healthy normal persons. They are not essential to life.
  • The normal microbial flora are of two types, residents and transients. The residents are permanent and cannot be completely remove, while the transients vary from time to time and are temporary.
  • MC resident organisms of upper respiratory tract is streptococci of viridans group. MC resident bacteria of large intestine is bacteroides species.
  • Mucus membranes of mouth and pharynx are often sterile at birth,  within 4-12 hrs after birth, viridans streptococci become establish as most prominent member of resident flora and remain so for life.
  • In the pharynx and trachea, similar flora establish itself whereas few bacteria are found in normal bronchi. Small bronchi and alveoli are normally sterile.
  • Stomach acidity keeps the number of microorganisms at a minimum (103-105, unless obstruction at the pylorus favours the proliferation of gram positive cocci and bacilli.
  • Antimicrobials drugs taken orally can, in humans, temporally suppress the drug susceptible components of the fecal flora.

questions.text: Agoraphobia is:

choices.text: Fear of places from where escape or help might be difficult

questions.solution:
Agoraphobia is characterized by the fear of places where escape or help might not be possible in case of a panic attack or another humiliating situation. These situations can include open spaces, public transit, shopping centers, or simply being outside their homes.

Agoraphobics tend to avoid these kinds of situations.

questions.text: With reference to Bacteroides fragilis the following statements are true except:

choices.text: B. fragilis is the most frequent anaerobe isolated from clinical samples
B. fragilis is not uniformly sensitive to metronidazole
The lipopolysaccharide formed by B. fragilis is structurally and functionally different from the conventional endotoxin
Shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation are common in Bacteroides bacteremia

questions.solution:
• Anaerobic Gram negative bacilli includes Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Leptotrichia, Porphyromonas, and Prevotella.
  • Bacteroides are MC anaerobes isolated from clinical specimen. Among them, B. fragilis is the most frequent of the non-sporing anaerobes isolated from clinical samples.
  • Bacteroides are Non-sporing, Non-motile, strict anaerobes and capsulated (Virulence factor).
  • They are classified on the basis of colonial, biochemical features (Saccharolytic effects) and on characteristics of short chain fatty acid patterns in gas liquid chromatography.
  • B fragilis possess lipopolysaccharides (endotoxin) that are less biologically potent than endotoxins associated with aerobic gram negative bacteria. Due to this relative biologic inactivity, bacteremia due to bacteroides do not directly produce signs of sepsis, which is common in other gram negative bacteria.
  • First line therapy for anaerobes includes Metronidazole, Ticarcillin/Clavulanic acid, Piperacillin/tazobactam, Imipenem.
  • Resistance to metronidazole is seen in <2% cases, i.e. not uniformly sensitive.
  • Bacteroides grows well on media such as brain heart infusion agar in an anaerobic atmosphere containing 10% CO2.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acceptable noise level?
questions.solution:
The upper limit of daily exposure to noise which people can tolerate without hearing damage is 85 dB. This is the maximum acceptable noise level.

Properties of Sound and Noise

I) Loudness

  • Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations and it is measured in decibels (dB).
  • The daily exposure of up to 85 dB is the limit that people can tolerate without substantial damage to hearing. This limit is the maximum acceptable noise limit.
Normal conversation 60 – 65 dB
Whispering 20 – 30 dB
Heavy street traffic 60 – 80 dB
Boiler factories 120 dB

 

  • Acceptable noise levels are expressed in terms of unit dBA, which is decibels conform to a weighting curve called curve A.
Area Place in area Acceptable noise levels (dBA)
Residential Bed room 25
  Living room 40
Commercial Office 35 – 45
  Conference 40 – 45
  Restaurants 40 – 60
Industrial Workshop 40 – 60
  Laboratory 40 – 50
Educational Classroom 30 – 40
  Library 35 – 40
Hospitals Wards 20 – 35

 

II) Frequency

  • It is expressed in Hertz (Hz.) and 1 Hertz is equal to one wave per second
  • The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz
  • Below 20 Hz. the vibrations are infra-audible and above 20,000 Hz. they are ultra-sonic

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to establish the importance of a particular amino acid residue in enzyme catalysis?
questions.solution:
Identification of active site residues:

  • Replacement or removal of an amino acid by site directed mutagenesis (amino acid is changed or removed at the gene level) is used to establish the importance of a particular amino acid residue in enzyme catalysis.
  • Diisopropylphosphofluoridate (DIPF) inactivates of trypsin, chymotrypsin and elastase.  This is due to the inactivation of serine residues of these enzymes.
    • As serine plays a crucial role in the catalysis, these three enzymes are known as serine proteases.

questions.text: This histopathological image of a 3 year old shows the presence of a mural nodule in posterior cranial fossa. Which tumor does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows the presence of a large cystic mass with an enhancing mural nodule in the cerebellum. Along with the age of the patient being 3 years indicates pilocytic astrocytoma.
  • Pilocytic astrocytoma (PA) is a low grade astrocytoma and is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. Its classic site of occurrence is the cerebellum but can occur in other parts of the CNS.
  • Another feature that helps in its diagnosis is the presence of Rosenthal fibres which are condensed masses of glial fragments.
  • PAs generally do not undergo malignant change and are rarely invasive.
  • Primary approach to treatment is surgical resection along with chemotherapy and radiation.

questions.text: The anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to SV2A synaptic vesicular protein is
questions.solution:
The anti-epileptic mechanism of action of levetiracetam appears to be due to its binding to SV2A synaptic vesicular protein. The exact mechanism on how the anti-epileptic action is exerted by binding to this receptor is unknown.

Options a and b: The exact mechanism of gabapentin and pregabalin is not known. Though they are GABA derivatives and designed as GABA agonists, they do not possess GABA mimetic activity in vitro. They may act through binding to specific type of Ca2+ channel subunit.

Option d: Zonisamide inhibits T type Ca2+ currents and also prolongs the inactivated state of Na+ channels.

questions.text: All of the following regarding gestational diabetes are true except

choices.text: Rate of fetal anomalies does not appear to be substantially increased in gestational diabetes than in overt diabetes
Neonatal hyperinsulinemia may provoke hypoglycemia within minutes of birth
The primary effect attributed to gestational diabetes is fetal macrosomia
Maternal obesity is not a confounding factor in the diagnosis of gestational diabetes

questions.solution:
Maternal obesity is an important confounding factor in the diagnosis of gestational diabetes.

Torloni and coworkers (2009) estimated that gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1% for every 1 Kg/m sq increase in BMI.

questions.text: “Pie in the sky” field defects are seen in
questions.solution:
Temporal lobe lesions produce pie in the sky defects.

Pie in the Sky defects:

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of inferior fibres of Optic radiations – Meyer’s loop
  • Seen in Temporal lobe lesions

Pie in the Floor defects:

  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of superior fibres of the Optic radiations – Baum’s loop
  • Seen in Parietal lobe lesions

 

Notable points :

  • Lesion in Central chiasma – Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Lesion in proximal part of optic nerve – Junctional scotoma
  • Lesion in optic tract – Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • Radiational lesion and cortical blindness has normal pupillary reaction

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The graph shows the UV absorption of amino acids in spectrophotometry. Red color line belongs to
questions.solution:
Because tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine, tryptophan makes the major contribution to the ability of most proteins to absorb light in the region of 280 nm.

Absorption of UV light by amino acids:

  • Amino acids do not absorb visible light and thus are colorless. 
  • However, tyrosine, phenylalanine, and especially tryptophan absorb high-wavelength (250-290 nm) ultraviolet light
  • Compounds with conjugated double bonds absorb UV light. That is why aromatic amino acids, porphyrins, purine and pyrimidine bases absorb UV light. Among the aromatic amino acids, tryptophan absorbs the maximum.
  • Light absorbing capacity of aromatic amino acids is used to estimate the protein concentration with spectrophotometer (instrument that can measure the light absorbance from infrared to ultraviolet range).
  • With the absorbance value of a known concentration of protein solutions, a standard curve is made. Concentration of the protein is calculated using the standard curve.

Light absorption wavelength range of compounds:

Compound λ max (nm)(wavelength at which maximal light absorption occurs)
Peptide bond 190 - 230
Purine and pyrimidine bases 260 
Aromatic amino acids 280 
NADH & NADPH 340 
Porphyrin 400

questions.text: All the following conditions present with secondary hemochromatosis except:
questions.solution:
Haemophilia does not present with secondary haemochromatosis.

The conditions presenting with secondary iron overload are:

  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Hereditary aceruloplasminemia

Secondary iron overload with deposition in parenchymal cells occurs in chronic disorders of erythropoiesis, as iron absorption is increased in these conditions. Moreover, these patients require blood transfusions and are frequently treated inappropriately with iron.

Hemophilia presents with mucosal bleeding which usually does not require blood transfusions. Furthermore, iron metabolism is normal in hemophilia. Therefore, secondary hemochromatosis is not seen in hemophilia.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is the "gold standard" for evaluating insulin resistance?

choices.text: Calculation of serum glucose: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
The "gold standard" for evaluating insulin resistance has been the hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp.

Unfortunately, this test is not practical in a clinical settingas:

  • Needs an IV line and
  • Needs frequent sampling
  • It is labor and time intensive

Hence, other less sensitive surrogate markers are used:

  • 2 hour glucose tolerance test
  • Fasting serum insulin level
  • Homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMAIR)
  • Quantitative insulin sensitivty check (QUICKI)
  • Calculation of serum glucose: insulin ratios

Of these tests, a 2 hour GTT is used frequently to exclude impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and type 2 DM.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mediator of opsonization?
questions.solution:
Opsonisation is mediated by C3b and its inactive iC3b

Complements :

  • The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and membrane receptors that function mainly in host defense against microbes and in pathologic inﬂammatory reactions.
  • The system consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 through C9
  • In the process of complement activation, several cleavage products of complement proteins are elaborated that cause increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, and opsonization.
  • The critical step in complement activation is the proteolysis of the third (and most abundant) component, C3.

Cleavage of C3 can occur by one of three pathways:

  • The classical pathway
  • The alternative pathway
  • The lectin pathway

Functions of complements :

  • C3a, C5a and  to a lesser extent C4a – Anaphylotoxins
  • C5a – Chemotaxis
  • C3b and inactive C3b – Opsonisation
  • C5b-9 – Membrane attack complex

choices.text: Larva parallel to undersurface of water

questions.solution:

  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: Treatment of ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Fasanella servat operation is done for cases of mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) with retained levator palpabrae superioris muscle function as seen in Horner’s syndrome.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the loss of sympathetic supply to the muller's muscle of the lid and not due to levator muscle palsy. Fasanella servat operation is not done in patients with severe ptosis and poor levtaor function.

Option A:Levator resection is performed for moderate and severe grades of ptosis but with retained levator function. This operation is contraindicated in patients with poor levator function.

Option B: Frontalis sling also known as Brow suspension is done in patients with severe ptosis with poor or absent levator muscle function. Here, the lid is anchored to the frontalis muscle via a sling. 

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis

Surgery Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Fasanella Servat < 2 mm -mild ptosis Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any amount (but with retained levator function) Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any amount (but with retained levator function) Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any amount (but with retained levator function) Acquired ptosis
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata >4 mm -severe ptosis Congenital ptosis – Marcus Gunn ptosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis that affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye?
questions.solution:
A nevus of Ota is associated with extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis that affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye and appears as shown in the image below. Lesions are more common in females.

It is usually distributed along the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve (nevus fuscoceruleus ophthalmaxillaris). Most of the lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, and increase in size and number during the subsequent years.

Other options:

  • Option a: Nevus of Ito: It presents as a unilateral, bluish, hyperpigmented patch that affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest (nevus fuscoceruleus acromiodeltoideus).
  • Option c: Lentigo simplex: It is the most common form of lentigo and presents as small pigmented spots on the skin with a clearly defined edge, surrounded by normal-looking skin. The lesions are light to dark-brown or black macule that does not fade away once it appears.
  • Option d: Hypomelanosis of Ito is a genetic disorder of pigmentation, which is characterized by symmetrical hypopigmented streaks or macules or patches, mostly over the back.

questions.text:
Type I endometrioid tumors spread in which of the following order of frequencies?
Direct extension - 1
Intraperitoneal exfoliation - 2
Hematogenous dissemination - 3
Lymphatic spread - 4
questions.solution:
Type I endometrioid tumors and their variants most commonly spread, in order of frequency by direct extension, lymphatic spread, hematogenous dissemination and intraperitoneal exfoliation

 

In general, the various patterns of spread are interrelated and often develop simultaneously.

questions.text: An elderly patient with type II diabetes presents with altered sensorium. He has not been eating or drinking well for the past few weeks. There are no complaints of nausea or abdominal pain. His blood sugar level is 800 mg/dL. All of the following are true regarding this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). In this condition, the anion gap is normal or slightly elevated, hence, option c- high anion gap is seen is a false statement.

HHS arises due to a relative reduction in circulating insulin and decreased fluid intake. Low level of insulin leads to a hyperglycemic state by two main mechanisms- increased glucose production by the liver and decreased glucose uptake by the skeletal muscles. This hyperglycemia results in osmotic diuresis, leading to volume depletion which is further exacerbated due to inadequate fluid intake by the patient. Eventually, kidney function is affected, reducing the glucose excretion through urine. All these factors result in a hyperosmolar state. 

Commonly seen in the elderly, HHS is usually precipitated by stressful events such as myocardial infarction, stroke, recent surgery, or infection. Certain drugs like steroids, diuretics, and phenytoin have also been implicated.

Symptoms of HHS include weakness, polyuria, and decreased oral intake. Symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis like nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are not usually seen. Hyperosmolarity can ultimately lead to altered sensorium, seizures, and coma. 

Laboratory investigations will show:

  • Blood sugar value >600 mg/dL
  • Sodium >135 meq/L
  • Moderately elevated creatinine due to prerenal azotemia
  • Osmolality between 330-380 mOsm/mL
  • pH >7.3
  • Normal to slightly elevated anion gap

A small anion gap metabolic acidosis may be seen, due to elevated lactic acid levels. Contrary to diabetic ketoacidosis, ketosis is usually not seen. 

Management includes treating the precipitating factor, fluid replacement, potassium supplementation based on serum potassium levels, and intravenous insulin. Once the patient can tolerate oral feeds, he can be started on subcutaneous insulin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the gynecologist with complaint of profuse vaginal discharge. There was no discharge from the cervical os on the speculum examination. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis was made based upon all of the following findings on microscopy except:
questions.solution:
Bacterial Vaginosis is defined as alteration in normal vaginal flora rather than true infection.

  • Causative organisms include: Gardnerella vaginalis or H. vaginalis, Mobiluncus
  • Microscopy of vaginal secretions in bacterial vaginosis shows: Characteristic clue cells, decreased or absent lactobacillus, decreased leucocytes.
  • Clinical criteria for diagnosis : Homogenous white non inflammatory discharge with fishy odour, Microscopic presence of >20% clue cells, Vaginal discharge with pH > 4.5 , Fishy odor with or without addition of 10% KOH.

Treatment: Metronidazole for both pregnant and non-pregnant women.

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The given mage shows the Triangle of Doom.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at the internal ring

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Staples are avoided in this region during hernia repair due to the risk of injury to the vessels which might result in severe hemorrhage.

Option a:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Superiorly by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Option b:

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle are:

  • Laterally by Inferior epigastric artery
  • Medially by the lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by the inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to the inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters the deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery)

Option d:

The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: Giant cell (Hecht's) pneumonia is due to?
questions.solution:
• Hecht's pneumonia, also known as giant cell pneumonia, is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition.

The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs.

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography can be performed alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is available for administration by transdermal therapeutic system?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is available to be administered in a transdermal therapeutic system (TTS).

Doses of TTS fentanyl include 20, 50, 75 and 100 μg/hour and achieve blood levels ranging from less than 1.0 to 2.0 ng/mL

Advantages of delivering fentanyl transdermally include:

  • Absence of first-pass drug metabolism by the liver
  • Improved patient compliance, convenience and comfort
  • Consistent analgesia

However, TTS fentanyl has the same adverse effects as other opioids, mainly sedation, nausea, vomiting, and constipation. In comparision with oral morphine, TTS fentanyl causes fewer gastrointestinal adverse events.

NOTE: Transdermal morphine is useful only if it is applied to de-epithelialized skin. Sufentanil and buprenorphine may also be suitable for transdermal delivery, but clinical results are not yet available. (Hence, best answer here is fentanyl)

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is being evaluated for recurrent febrile urinary tract infections. A micturating cystourethrogram was done as shown. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Surgical repair reverses renal scarring and improves function
Nephrectomy is indicated if affected kidney has poor function
An open ureteral implantation has a high success rate for grades I-IV
Antibiotic prophylaxis is the recommended initial approach

questions.solution:
In the above scenario with a boy with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and the micturating cystourethrogram showing bilaterally dilated ureters is suggestive of bilateral vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). Surgical repair will not reverse renal scarring or cause improvement in renal function. The goal of surgery is to minimize the risk of febrile UTIs from ongoing VUR.

Vesicoureteric or vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a condition in which there is a retrograde urinary flow from the bladder to the kidney and ureter. It is usually a congenital familial disorder with an autosomal dominant transmission.

VUR can cause urinary stasis and lead to urinary tract infection (UTI). It also predisposes to pyelonephritis and which can lead to renal scarring due to parenchymal inflammation. This is known as reflux nephropathy. 

Micturating cystogram is used to confirm the VUR. VUR can be graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on the micturating cystogram. It is as follows:

Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter.
Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation.
Grade III: VUR into a dilated ureter and/or blunting of the calyceal fornices.
Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter.
Grade V: massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

The initial approach to management includes daily antibiotic prophylaxis to reduce the risk of UTIs and subsequent renal scarring.

Surgical repair can be done via open, laparoscopic, and endoscopic methods. Various procedures performed include:

  • Ureteral narrowing using psoas hitch- in cases with a megaureter
  • Nephrectomy or nephroureterectomy- if refluxing kidney function is very poor
  • Ureteral reimplantation- this has a success rate of >95–98% for grades I-IV
  • Endoscopic repair of VUR- non-invasive and used for lower grades of VUR. It involves the injection of a bulking agent through a cystoscope just beneath the ureteral orifice, creating an effective flap-valve

Surgical repair will not reverse renal scarring or cause improvement in renal function.

questions.text: Which amino acid on ninhydrin test gives a yellow colour complex?
questions.solution:
All amino acids form purple complex with ninhydrin except for Proline and hydroxyl proline which forms yellow colour complex.

Ninhydrin test :

  • Ninhydrin reaction is one of the most important reactions used for the qualitative detection of hydrolytic products of protein i.e. amino acids.  All amino acids give positive ninhydrin reaction.
  • Principle:
  • The amino acids are deaminated to CO2, NH3 and an aldehyde under heat. Ninhydrin reacts with NH3 and forms a purple coloured complex, which can be measured at 570 nm.
  • All amino acids, except proline, react with ninhydrin at ambient temperature, to form a blue colored complex, which intensifies to purple on heating.
  • Proline forms a yellow coloured complex

The complex formed by ninhydrin is known as Ruhemann’s purple.

questions.text: Pearson formula is used to estimate
questions.solution:
Pearson formula is used for the estimation of stature.

This mathematical formula can be used to estimate the length of the long bones to identify the stature of the individual from the skeletal remains that are incomplete or severely disintegrated. It uses different calculating factors for bones from males and females based on whether the bones are wet (intact cartilage) or dried (devoid of cartilage). This method was used for a long time in European subjects.

For each long bone, there is a separate multiplying factor and a constant factor. The constant factor is added to the product of the length of the long bone and multiplying factor. The addition of certain values for the soft parts is also done. 

Other formulas for stature estimation: 

  • Trotter and Gleser formula
  • Dupertuis and Hadden formula
  • Steele formula

questions.text: Which of the following has no anti-factor IIa activity?
questions.solution:
Fondaparinux has no anti-factor IIa activity. It is a synthetic pentasaccharide that binds and activates antithrombin.

Activation of antithrombin causes the inactivation of factor Xa. Fondaparinux does not have any anti-factor IIa activity as it is not long enough to form a template for thrombin(IIa) and antithrombin binding and subsequent inhibition of thrombin.

For antithrombin activity, the heparin molecules should be of sufficient length (>18 polysaccharide units) to serve as a template for thrombin and antithrombin binding.

Other options:

Option A - Unfractionated heparin has sufficient length for inhibition of thrombin activity so that the factor Xa: IIa inhibition activity is 1:1.

Options B, D - Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) - Enoxaparin and Dalteparin have sufficient length for inhibition of thrombin activity, but less compared to unfractionated heparin. The factor Xa: IIa inhibition activity ranges from 2:1 to 3:1 depending upon the preparation.

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is associated with
questions.solution:
Prilocaine is an intermediate acting amino amide local anesthetic. It is unique among local anesthetics because of its propensity to cause methemoglobinemia.

Methhemoglobinemia is due to metabolism of the aromatic ring to O-toluidine and is dose dependent.

Benzocaine also causes methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with features of facial nerve palsy. On examination, schirmer test is normal, stapedial reflex is normal but taste sensation is impaired and corneal reflex is reduced. Probable site of lesion is
questions.solution:
Since schirmer test is normal – greater superficial petrosal nerve arising from geniculate ganglion situated in first genu is normal.

Since stapedial reflex is normal, injury is not proximal to second genu.

Loss of taste sensation implies injury to chorda tympani given by the vertical descending part of facial nerve i.e. beyond second genu.

Topodiagnostic tests:

These tests help to detect site of lesion of facial nerve.

  • Schirmer’s test to test lacrimation
  • Stapedial reflex tested by tympanometry
  • Electrogustometry to test taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue
  • Salivary flow studies

Interpretation:

  • Schirmer’s test is normal but stapedial reflex absent – injury is beyond geniculate ganglion. Greater superficial petrosal nerve supplying lacrimal, nasal, palatine glands is normal.
  • Stapedial reflex is normal but loss of taste in anterior 2/3rd of tongue – injury is beyond the level of pyramid since nerve to stapedius is given off at the level of pyramid.
  • Taste sensation normal but reduced corneal reflex – injury beyond chorda tympani nerve in vertical segment.
  • If schirmer’s test, stapedial reflex, taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and corneal reflex are all absent, it indicates injury proximal to geniculate ganglion i.e. in labyrinthine segment.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a distinguishing feature of Munchausen syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Munchausen syndrome is chronic factitious disorder with predominantly physical signs and symptoms.
  • It is a severe form of factitious disorder in which the factitious illness behavior becomes a lifestyle.
  • Those suffering from this condition are nicknamed hospital hoboes, hospital addicts or professional patients.
  • Two distinguishing features of this syndrome are pseudologica fantastica (lying with fascinating tales based on a truth) and peregrination (well traveled).
  • These patients tend to be well traveled as they go from hospital to hospital, gaining notice and then move to another place to start anew.
  • Hypochondriasis is a condition in which a person is preoccupied with physical symptom and believes them to be due to an underlying illness even though the opposite has been proven with tests and other evidence.
  • Anhedonia is the inability to feel pleasure in normal, pleasurable activities. It can be a sign of sexual disorders.
  • Trichotillomania is an impulse-control disorder in which there is an irresistible urge to pull out body hair.

questions.text: All of the following are true about giant cell tumor of bone except:

choices.text: Common in age group between 20 and 40 years
Giant cells are the proliferative component of the tumor
Locally aggressive tumor which may have lung metastases

questions.solution:
• Giant cells are not the proliferative component of giant cell tumor. Mononuclear stromal cells are the proliferative component.
  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors show many multinucleated giant cells in a sea of proliferating mononuclear stromal cells.
  • Giant cell tumors generally present at 20 to 40 years of age. It has a slight female predominance.
    • Although these tumors are benign, they are locally aggressive and patients can develop lung metastases.

questions.text: If a chromosome divides in axis perpendicular to the usual axis of division, it forms:
questions.solution:
Chromosomal structural aberrations :

  • Isochromosome formation results when one arm of a chromosome is lost and the remaining arm is duplicated, resulting in a chromosome consisting of two short arms or of two long arms
  • Caused by centromere misdivision leading to formation of isochromosome , the axis of division being perpendicular to the usual axis of division
  • A ring chromosome is a special form of deletion produced when a break occurs at both ends of a chromosome with the fusion of the damaged ends.
  • Ring chromosomes do not behave normally in meiosis or mitosis and usually result in serious consequences
  • In a translocation, a segment of one chromosome is transferred to another.
  • Inversion refers to a rearrangement that involves two breaks within a single chromosome with reincorporation of the inverted, intervening segment.

Isochromosomes:

  • Microphthalmia
  • Polydactyly
