questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his mouth. On examination, several purplish papules were noted on his shins. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lichen planus with the image showing whitish lines visible typically in the oral mucosa, known as the Wickam's striae.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease like:

  • Viruses like: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 P"s of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

Complications of lichen planus includes:

  • Hair: Patches of cicatricial scarring alopecia
  • Nails: Various nail changes are seen associated with lichen planus. 
    • Dorsal Nail Pterygium: Most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.
    • Thinning of the nail plate: Most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
    • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of nail in the shape of a tent
    • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
    • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
    • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

questions.text: Which of the following protein is involved in the absorption of calcium in the intestine?
questions.solution:
• Ca2+ is transported across the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells via channels known as transient receptor potential vanilloid type 6 (TRPV6) and binds to an intracellular protein known as calbindin-D.
  • Calbindin sequesters the absorbed calcium so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.
  • The absorbed Ca2+ is thereby delivered to the basolateral membrane of the epithelial cell, from where it can be transported into the bloodstream by either a sodium/calcium exchanger (NCX1), Ca2+ - Mg2+ ATPase, or PMCA1b
  • The overall transport process is regulated by 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.

questions.text: Which hormone acts on JAK-STAT kinase receptor?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone acts on JAK-STAT receptors.

Janus tyrosine kinase receptors (JAK-STAT) serves as receptors for:

  • Growth hormone
  • Prolactin
  • Erythropoietin
  • Leptin

Thyroxine acts on nuclear receptors. TSH and FSH act on G protein-coupled receptors.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens

Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors

Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

Gastrin
Cholecystokinin

cGMP:

2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Tight junctions are not seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Tight junctions are not seen in cardiac muscle. 

Tight junctions form a water-tight seal between cells. They are characteristically seen in the following:

  • Intestinal mucosa
  • Renal tubules
  • Choroid plexus
  • Sertoli cells

Functions of tight junctions are:

  • Prevents the diffusion of macromolecules between cells.
  • Maintains cell polarity.
  • Seals the paracellular pathway.

questions.text: The term microcephaly is defined as occipitofrontal circumference
questions.solution:
Microcephaly is defined as a head circumference that measures more than 3 SD below the mean for age and sex.

Megalencephaly is an anatomic disorder of brain growth defined as a brain weight : volume ratio >98th percentile for age (or ≥2 SD above the mean) that is usually accompanied by macrocephaly (an occipitofrontal circumference >98th percentile).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Neurological Impairment Scale?

choices.text: It is based on the Frankel classification of spinal cord injury
Motor function is assessed using Medical Research Council grading system of 0-4
Normal functional motor power is grade 2/4 or higher
According to scale D, sensation is present, motor is absent

questions.solution:
The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) neurological evaluation system is an internationally accepted method of neurological evaluation and is based on the Frankel classification of spinal cord injury.

Option b

Motor function is assessed using the Medical Research Council (MRC) grading system (0–5).

Option c

Normal functional motor power is grade 3/5 or higher.

Option d

According to the impairment scale D, the sensation is present and the motor is useful (MRC grade more than or equal to 3/5).

According to the medical research council grading of muscle power, grade 4 is an active movement against resistance but power is less than full. And grade 5 corresponds to normal power.

Related Pearl: Neurological Impairment Examination

The Medical Research Council (MRC) grading of muscle power

Grading Description
0 No movement
1 Flicker of movements
2 Active movement with gravity elimination
3 Active movement against gravity
4 Active movement against resistance but power less than full
5 Normal power

The ASIA (American Spinal Injury Association) neurological impairment scale:

Impairment scale Description
A Complete impairment
B Sensation present, motor absent
C Sensation present, motor present, but not useful (MRC grade less than 3/5)
D Sensation present, motor useful (MRC grade more than equal to 3/5)
E Normal functions

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is seen in the emergency department after he had collapsed after a dental extraction in which topical anesthesia was used. The patient is deeply cyanosed despite a good respiratory effort, a clear airway, and bilateral breath sounds. Although he initially responds to vocal commands, his level of consciousness soon deteriorates. Oxygen saturation is 60% with the patient breathing room air. An endotracheal tube is introduced and assisted ventilation started, but this does not improve his cyanosis or level of consciousness. Which of the following topical anesthetics could be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of methemoglobinemia, which is common side effect with prilocaine.

  • The possible diagnosis of methemoglobinemia can be made because the patient is cyanosed, the cyanosis is unresponsive to ventilation, there is no prior history of respiratory problems, and the patient had been exposed to a topical anesthetic that is known to cause methemoglobinemia.
  • Hepatic metabolism of prilocaine generates O-toluidine, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin.

Treatment:

  • Severe methemoglobinemia is a medical emergency, requiring prompt recognition and appropriate treatment.
  • It can be treated with intravenous administration of methylene blue, whose action depends on the availability of reduced nicotinamide adenine nucleotide phosphate (NADPH) within the red blood cell.
  • Dextrose should be givenas the major source of NADH in the red blood cells is the catabolism of sugar through glycolysis.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding Interleukin- 1:

choices.text: Its production is stimulated by prostaglandins
Induces growth of all hematopoietic cells
Induces the maturation of IL-2 producing lymphocytes

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding IL-1 is that induces the maturation of IL-2 producing lymphocytes.

The Interleukin-1 family (IL-1 family) is a group cytokines, which plays a central role in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses to infections or sterile insults.

IL-1 is a stable polypeptide that occurs in two molecular forms, IL-1α and IL-1β. 

It is principally secreted by macrophages and monocytes but is also expressed in the thymus, spleen, lymph nodes, Peyer’s patches, and bone marrow. In non-lymphoid organs, IL-1α and IL-1β are expressed in tissue macrophages in the lung, digestive tract, and liver.

Its production is stimulated by antigens, toxins, injury, and inflammatory processes. Production of IL-1 is inhibited by cyclosporin-A, corticosteroids, and prostaglandins.

It stimulates T cells for the production of IL-2 and in addition, also stimulates B cell proliferation and antibody synthesis, neutrophil chemotaxis, and phagocytosis.

IL1 is an important endogenous pyrogen. Along with the tumor necrosis factor (TNF), it is responsible for many of the hematological changes in septic shock and inflammation in bacterial meningitis. While cytokine inhibitors such as dexamethasone are protective against the sequelae of such excessive meningeal inflammation, at the same time, IL 1 has a beneficial effect in severe infections in immunocompromised hosts.

Other options:

IL-3 can induce the growth of all types of hematopoietic cells. Hence, it is called a multi-CSF (colony-stimulating factor).

IL-2 is responsible for the conversion of null cells (LGL) into lymphokine-activated killer cells (LAK) which can destroy NK-resistant tumor cells.

questions.text: The structure that lies superficial to the flexor retinaculum is _________
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve and vessels pass superficial to flexor retinaculum.

  • It is attached medially to the pisiform bone and the hook of the hamate bone. Laterally, it splits into superficial and deep laminae.

The structures lying deep to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Lateral compartment:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Medial compartment:
    • Median nerve
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • 4 tendons each of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus

Structures lying superficial to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Palmaris longus tendon
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar vessels

questions.text: True regarding receptor activator of nuclear factor (RANK) ligand pathway

choices.text: RANK ligand is expressed by Osteoclasts
Osteoprotegerin (OPG) is a natural activator of RANK ligand
Osteoblasts secrete HCl and collagen dissolving enzymes
Estrogen limits the expression of RANK ligand

questions.solution:
Estrogen is a negative regulator of the osteoclast activity and it limits the expression of RANK ligand from osteoblasts.

  • Option a

RANK ligand is expressed by osteoblasts and the ligand binds to RANK receptor on osteoclasts and osteoclast precursors.

  • Option b

Osteoprotegerin (OPG) is a natural inhibitor of RANK ligand

  • Option c

Bone resorption is carried out by osteoclasts and bone formation is carried out by osteoblasts.

Key components of the RANKL/RANK/OPG pathway

  • RANKL( RANK ligand)
    • Protein expressed by osteoblasts
    • Binds to RANK on osteoclasts
    • Activation of RANK promotes osteoclast formation, funciton, survival
  • RANK
    • Expressed by osteoclasts and their precursor
    • Activated by RANKL binding
  • Osteoprotegerin (OPG)
    • Protein secreted by osteoblasts
    • Natural inhibitor of RANKL
    • Blocks RANKL mediated activation of RANK to balance bone remodeling

In healthy premenopausal women, estrogen limits the expression of RANKL. OPG binds to RANKL to further limit its availability to stimulate osteoclasts. The remaining RANKL will bind to osteoclast precursors which form differentiated osteoclasts for bone resorption. This is followed by appearance of osteoblasts resulting in bone formation.

To sum up, resorption and bone formation are balanced in premenopausal women.

In postmenopausal women, decreased estrogen will lead to increased RANKL expression, which may overwhelm natural activity of OPG thus leading to more bone resorption and potentially postmenopausal osteoporosis.

questions.text: The finding seen in this Xray?

choices.text: Periarticular erosions with over hanging edges

questions.solution:
The image shows Martel’s sign which is characteristic of gouty lesions with punched out lesions and periarticular erosions with overhanging margins.

  • During acute attack x rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary osteoarthritis.
  • Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel's sign or G sign).
  • These well defined erosions are larger and slightly further from the joint margin than typical rheumatoid arthritis erosions.

questions.text: The cingulum of the brain is classified under ____________.
questions.solution:
The cingulum of the brain is classified under long association fibers.

The cingulum lies within the cingulate gyrus, connecting the frontal and parietal lobes with the parahippocampal and temporal cortical regions

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: The absorption spectrum given in the image below belongs to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The absorption spectrum given in the image below shows increased absorption at 400nm. Porphyrins absorb UV light at 400nm.

Conjugated double bonds in the porphyrin rings absorb light at the UV spectrum. The maximum absorbance of porphyrins is around 400 nm. This peak is known as Soret band.

The conjugated double bonds in the pyrrole rings and linking methylene groups of porphyrins (absent in the porphyrinogens) are responsible for their characteristic absorption and fluorescence spectra.

questions.text:
A patient with a testicular tumor is also found to have parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

MEN: multiple endocrine neoplasia
questions.solution:
The most appropriate diagnosis, in this case, is MEN 4. 

Tumors associated with MEN 1 are parathyroid adenomas, pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs) such as gastrinoma and insulinoma. When they occur in association with gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors, the patient is designated to have MEN 4 syndrome. 

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: In a postoperative ward, 4 out of 10 patients developed wound discharge, which on culture and antibiotic susceptibility was found to be positive for coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci, resistant to Methicillin. Which of the following is true regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Major route of spread  is air borne
Alteration in its penicillin binding proteins is found
Sensitive to amoxicillin + clavulanic acid combination

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infections occurring in the post-operative ward and the culture and antibiotic susceptibility report suggest methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Alteration in its penicillin-binding proteins is found in MRSA.

Staphylococci are gram-positive cocci arranged characteristically in grape-like clusters. They are uniformly resistant to lysozymes. 

They exhibit various types of resistance to antibiotics by beta-lactamase production and alteration in penicillin-binding protein PBP2a. 

Beta-lactamase or penicillinase-producing strains inactivate penicillin by splitting the beta-lactam ring. The beta-lactamase enzyme is plasmid-mediated. However, they are susceptible to penicillinase-resistant penicillins such as methicillin and cloxacillin. This can be transmitted by transduction or conjugation. 

Alteration of PBP2a leads to changes in surface binding of beta-lactam antibiotics on bacteria resulting in resistance to all beta-lactam antibiotics and is termed methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The mechanism of resistance of MRSA is due to chromosomally mediated Mec A gene which codes for altered PBP2a (Penicillin Binding Protein or receptor 2a) which has less affinity for beta-lactam drugs.

Other options:

Option A: The major route of spread causing the outbreak is direct contact through the contaminated hands of hospital staff or direct contact with an infected wound.

Option B: The resistance to Methicillin is chromosomally mediated.

Option D: Since MRSA-coded altered PBP 2a (Penicillin Binding protein 2a) has less affinity for lactam drugs, MRSA strains are resistant to all beta-lactam drugs. Even a combination of β lactam and β lactamase inhibitor will not work.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Winking owl sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
• One of the first clues of vertebral compromise, especially in the case of vertebral metastases, is the winking owl sign seen in anteroposterior radiograph. This is due to obliteration of pedicles on one side.
  • If pedicles are obliterated on both sides, it is called the blind owl sign.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about pemphigus vulgaris except ______

choices.text: Desmoglein 1 is the principal antigen implicated in the disease
The bullae are flaccid and are filled with clear fluid
Penicillamine is the most common drug inducing pemphigus vulgaris

questions.solution:
In Pemphigus Vulgaris, desmoglein 3 is the principal antigen against which autoantibodies are produced.

Pemphigus Vulgaris is an immunobullous disease or a chronic blistering disease which occurs due to an autoimmune process, by the production of antibodies (usually IgG) against desmosomes (adhesion proteins).

Oral erosions usually precede the skin manifestations. Other mucosal lesions involve conjunctiva, larynx, pharynx, esophagus, etc.

The skin manifestations include flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid and erythematous base which rupture to produce painful erosions. These are mostly present over the face, scalp, upper chest, back, and neck.

Drug-induced Pemphigus: Penicillamine (Thiol group) is the most common drug implicated in Drug-induced pemphigus.

It usually occurs after 1 year of taking the drug and is seen in patients who are suffering from other autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

Non-thiol drugs which are associated with Drug-induced pemphigus are ACE Inhibitors and glibenclamide.

Phenol group (Cephalosporins, Rifampicin, Phenobarbital, and Aspirin) may also cause Drug-Induced Pemphigus.

questions.text: Appropriate statistical method to compare proportions is:
questions.solution:
• Chi-square tests are best used in comparing proportions.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Patients sometimes complain that the condition in the image given below gives them a hamster-like appearance. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a non-inflammatory swelling particularly affecting the parotid gland
Most patients present between 40 to 70 years of age
The salivary swellings are soft and asymmetrical
Drug induced lesion is particularly common with sympathomimetic drugs

questions.solution:
The given image is of sialadenosis or sialosis where the salivary swellings are soft and often symmetrical. When parotid glands are affected, patients may complain of a hamster-like appearance.

The above image is of a man with sialosis of the parotid glands secondary to excess alcohol intake. 

Sialadenosis (sialosis) is a non-inﬂammatory swelling particularly affecting the parotid gland. It usually occurs in association with a variety of conditions including:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Alcoholism
  • Other endocrine diseases
  • Pregnancy
  • Drugs
  • Bulimia and other eating disorders
  • Idiopathic diseases

The treatment of sialosis is unsatisfactory, but treatment is aimed at the correction of the underlying disorder. Drug associated sialadenosis may regress when the drug responsible is withdrawn.

questions.text: Analysis of the IFN-gamma responses of whole blood cells from BCG-vaccinated or non-BCG-vaccinated donors or patients with tuberculosis, stimulated with PPD, ESAT-6 or CFP-10 antigens, and evaluation of the specificity and sensitivity of the test INF-gamma assay in TB is done. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: ESAT and CFP-10 cannot differentiate between mycobacteria and other atypical mycobacteria
Replacing the PPD test for screening of tuberculosis

questions.solution:
'IFN-γ Release Assays (IGRAs) are more specific than the Tuberculin Skin Testing (TST) as a result of less cross-reactivity due to BCG vaccination and sensitization by nontuberculous mycobacteria.’

Interferon gamma release assay uses Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigen CFP10 which reacts with the T-lymphocytes of the patient to release gamma interferon.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of prerenal azotemia?
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyolysis causes intrinsic kidney injury. It is not a cause of Prerenal kidney injury.

The causes of acute injury of kidney can be classified as

  • Prerenal
  • Renal
  • Postrenal

questions.text: All are false regarding serous tumours of the ovary except

choices.text: High-grade tumors have a high frequency of TP53 mutations

questions.solution:
High-grade serous tumors are associated with high frequency of TP53 mutations

Serous tumors of ovary :

  • Serous carcinomas of ovary include the most common malignant ovarian tumors and account for approximately 40% of all cancers of the ovary.
  • Low-grade tumors - mutations in the KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 oncogenes
  • High-grade tumors - high frequency of TP53 mutations
  • Bilaterality is common

Concentric calcifications (psammoma bodies) characterize serous tumors but are not specific for neoplasia

NOTE: The question asks all are false except, hence it is asking the true statement.

questions.text: Spaghetti and meatball appearance on KOH mount is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In pityriasis versicolor (tinea versicolor), KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and a large number of variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes), collectively referred to as the spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

This is shown in the image below:


It is most commonly caused by Malassezia globosa and may also be caused by Malassezia furfur and Malassezia sympodialis. A Wood's lamp examination is useful in diagnosing the condition.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Faint yellow

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

questions.text: The following is  a vector for:
questions.solution:
• Soft ticks are the vectors for relapsing fever.
  • Hard ticks are vectors for tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Calorific value of alcohol is _____
questions.solution:
The calorific value of alcohol is 7 kcal/gm.

(ALCOHOL is a 7-letter word.)

  • Calorific value of alcohol is higher than carbohydrate and proteins. But all these calories are empty calories.
  • Empty calories are those which are not accompanied by micronutrients (vitamins & minerals).
Food Stuff Calorific value (Cal/gm)
Carbohydrates 4.0
Proteins 4.2
Fat 9.0
Alcohol 7

questions.text: A 27 year old male presents with diarrhoea, confusion, high grade fever and bilateral pneumonitis. Which pathogenic agent is the suspected?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia due to legionella is associated with high grade fever, confusion and diarrhea.

Legionnaire’s disease:-

  • Presents as atypical pneumonia
  • Source of infections: aerosols
  • Risk factors:-
    • Advanced age
    • Immunocompromised patients
    • Chronic smoking
    • Long standing lung disease

Presents as mild cough with slightly productive sputum, high fever and non specific symptoms like malaise, fatigue, anorexia and diarrhoea.

Drugs of choice: Azithromycin and respiratory quinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin)

questions.text: A patient shows FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted, under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted is classified as severe COPD under GOLD classification.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

  GOLD Stage   Severity   Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: The more potent warfarin enantiomer is primarily metabolised by
questions.solution:
Warfarin is administered as racemic mixture.

S-warfarin is 3-5 times more potent than R-warfarin and is mainly metabolised by CYP2C9.

Genetic polymorphisms of CYP2C9 can result in variable response to warfarin administration. 

Options a, c and d: CYP2C19, CYP3A4 and CYP1A2 is involved in the metabolism of less potent R-warfarin.

questions.text: The annulus of Vieussens is formed by the anastomoses between _______

choices.text: Right coronary artery and left coronary artery
Right conal artery and left conal artery
Anterior interventricular artery and Left coronary artery
Right coronary artery and Posterior interventricular artery

questions.solution:
The annulus of Vieussens also called pre-conal ring, is a collateral arterial ring present at the area of sub-pulmonary infundibulum.

It is formed by the anastomoses between:

  • Right conal artery: Branch of right coronary artery
  • Left conal artery: Branch of anterior interventricular artery

The above image shows preconal, retroconal, and retroaortic arterial anastomoses.

Other anastomotic rings:

  • The retroconal anastomotic ring forms connections from the right and left coronaries through collaterals which traverse in the interarterial space behind the main pulmonary artery but anterior to the ascending aorta.

The retroaortic anastomotic ring, otherwise known as the Kugel atrial anastomotic network, communicates the proximal right and left coronary systems or individually with a distal coronary system through the interatrial septum.

questions.text: When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to:

choices.text: Increase because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic baroreceptors
Increase because epinephrine has a direct chronotropic effect on the heart
Increase because of increased tonic parasympathetic discharge to the heart
Decrease because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic chemoreceptors

questions.solution:
When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to increase because it has direct chronotrophic effect on heart.

Effect of Catecholamines on Heart

Both epinephrine and norepinephrine –

  • Increase the force and rate of contraction of the heart by β1-receptors.
  • Increase myocardial excitability, causing extrasystoles and occasionally cardiac arrhythmias.

The differences in the effects are given in the table below 

Norepinephrine

Epinephrine

vasoconstriction via α1-receptors

Vasodilatation in skeletal muscle and the liver via β2-receptors. 

Norepinephrine -> Increases systolic and diastolic blood pressures -> stimulation of carotid and aortic baroreceptors -> reflex bradycardia -> overrides cardio acceleratory effect of norepi­nephrine->cardiac output falls.

Epi­nephrine causes a widening of the pulse pressure but because baroreceptor stimulation is insufficient to obscure the direct effect of the epinephrine on the heart, cardiac rate, and output increase.

questions.text: Which of the following forms anterior boundary of epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
The hepatoduodenal ligament, which is formed by the thickened free right margin of the lesser omentum, forms the anterior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

Within this free border lies the following structures:

  • Bile duct (anteriorly on the right)
  • Hepatic artery (anteriorly on the left)
  • Portal vein (posteriorly)

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac):

  • It is a short, vertical slit, about 3 cm in height in adults, behind the free right border of the lesser omentum.
  • It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Free margin of lesser omentum containing hepatic artery, portal vein, bile duct.
  • Posterior – T12 vertebra, Inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – caudate lobe of liver
  • Inferior – First part of duodenum

questions.solution:
Early adolescence is between 10-13 years

Adolescence is defined from 10 to 19 years

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mallampati classification except _______

choices.text: It is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation
Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures
Only hard palate is visualised in Class III
Tonsillar pillars are visualised in Class I

questions.solution:
• Only the hard palate is visualized in Class IV of Mallampati classification.

Mallampati classification is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation based on the size of the base of the tongue.

  • The patient is seated upright with the head neutral, and mouth open, the tongue protruded, and no phonation (Patient should NOT say 'aah').
  • A Mallampati classification of I to IV is assigned, based on the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate.
  • Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures attributable to a large tongue relative to the size of the oropharyngeal space, and, subsequently, leading to more difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to otosclerosis
questions.solution:
Hitzelberger sign is hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall seen in a case of acoustic neuroma with facial nerve involvement.

Option a: Carhartz notch is a typical dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000Hz in an audiogram.

Option c: A ‘flamingo flush’ or Schwartz sign is the red blush of the tympanic membrane over the promontory. It is said to be due to the vascularity of an active otosclerotic focus but is rarely seen.

Option d: Paracusis willisii is a phenomenon where a patient hears better in noisy surroundings.

questions.text: Prostaglandin derivative indicated in constipation predominant irritable bowel syndrome
questions.solution:
Lubiprostone is a bicyclic fatty acid derivative obtained from PGE1.

Lubiprostone acts by stimulating the Cl- channels opening in the intestine, increasing liquid secretion in the gut and thus decreasing the transit time.

Lubipristone is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in females >18 years).

questions.solution: Since Nocardia are among the few aerobic microorganisms that use paraffin as a carbon source, paraffin baiting can be used to isolate the organisms from mixed culture'.

questions.text: The cells shown in this image represent:
questions.solution:
• Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
  • In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces, where they are phagocytosed and digested by macrophages, which store the iron recovered from hemoglobin in the form of hemosiderin.
  • These hemosiderin-laden macrophages (also known as heart failure cells) are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
• Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator.
  • Spells of sickness and notification rates are morbidity indicators
  • Quality-adjusted life-years is a disability rate.

Disability indicators:

  1. HALE - Health Adjusted Life Expectancy
  2. QALY - Quality Adjusted Life Years
  3. Active Life Expectancy / Disability free life expectancy
  4. DALY - Disability Adjusted Life Years

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells.

It is characterized by:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

Management of TLS includes

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkanization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase

questions.text: Recently, a new latex agglutination test was approved for the screening of a disease. Calculate the sensitivity and specificity based on the table given below:
questions.solution:
• Let us first reconstruct the table to indicate true (TP/TN) and false (FP/FN) positives and negatives.
  Test + Test -
Diseased 27 (TP) 3 (FN)
Not diseased 5 (FP) 95 (TN)
  • Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 and specificity is given as TN/(FP + TN) x 100
  • In this scenario, sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.

Mean and median values of the given data

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in the management of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Clindamycin is a broad spectrum lincosamide antibiotic. It is one of the most common antibiotics implicated in Clostridium difficile associated bacterial infections. Therefore, clindamycin is a causative agent for Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea and not used in the management.

First choice treatment of C. difficile Colitis :

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin / Fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin / Fidaxomicin 
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin / Fidaxomicin

*Metronidazole now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue.

questions.text: Astrocytomas are associated with all of the following gene defects except
questions.solution: Commonly primary brain tumors occur sporadically and there is no proven risk due to environmental factors but genetic abnormalities may predispose brain tumors.

questions.text: 25% of the population of a community is under 15 years of age and 15% are over 65. What is the dependency ratio of this community?
questions.solution:
Total dependency ratio in this community is 67%. It can be calculated by the folowing formula;

Total dependency ratio = (Total population below 15 years and 65 years and above) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64)

In this scenario, total dependency ratio = (25% + 15%) x 100/ 60% = 4000/60 = 66.66 = 67%.

questions.text: The section of the rectus sheath as shown in the image below is taken____
questions.solution:
The above section of rectus sheath is taken above the arcuate line, which corresponds to approximately one-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the pubis.

Although , a section below the umbilicus could be similar to that of a section above the arcuate line,the single best answer would be above the arcuate line.

 

  • The rectus sheath is a fibrous sheath which encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. Each aponeurosis is bilaminar.
  • The anterior portion of this sheath extends the entire length of the muscle and fuses with periosteum and ligaments at sites of the muscle’s attachments.
  • The posterior part of the sheath is complete behind the upper two-thirds of the muscle but absent below the arcuate line. Below this level, rectus abdominis lies on the transversalis fascia and extraperitoneal connective tissue.

The composition of the rectus sheath is as follows

Above the arcuate line:

  • The anterior wall of the rectus sheath is formed by both laminae of external oblique and anterior lamina of internal oblique
  • The posterior wall is formed by posterior lamina of internal oblique and both laminae of transversus abdominis

Below the arcuate line:

  • All three aponeuroses from the external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles pass into the anterior rectus sheath.

questions.text: A patient comes to hospital with history of diarrhoea for 3 weeks and a high risk behaviour (sexual contact with unknown source) 6 months back. The testing for HIV status as per NACO strategy for HIV diagnosis comes under:
questions.solution:
NACO strategic plans/algorithms refers to selecting the best type of test, or more than one type of test, for identifying and confirming HIV in various situations.

  1. Strategy I: It is done for blood donors in blood banks. Only one test is done.
  2. Strategy IIa: It is done for seroprevalence or epidemiological purpose, i.e., used in sentinel surveillance. Two tests are done.
  3. Strategy IIb: Purpose: It is followed for the diagnosis of HIV/AIDS in symptomatic patients. Two tests are done.
  4. Strategy III: It is done for the diagnosis of asymptomatic HIV patients, antenatal screening and screening of patients awaiting surgeries. Three tests are done.

questions.text: The best treatment for a newly detected unilateral idiopathic club foot in a one year old child is:
questions.solution:
• Ponseti casting in the initial non-operative treatment for most cases of clubfoot, especially in those presenting as a case of unilateral idiopathic clubfoot in early life.
  • Kite’s reduction is no longer used.
  • Lambrinudi procedure and posteromedial soft tissue release are operative methods of clubfoot correction. These are used only when clubfoot presents in later life and also when conservative methods do not produce results.

questions.text: The deficiency or absence of which of the following proteins in the skin leads to the development of ichthyosis vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant disorder, which occurs due to reduced or absent filaggrin protein and granular layer.

Filaggrin is essential for the regulation of epidermal homeostasis. Within the stratum corneum, filaggrin monomers can become incorporated into the lipid envelope, which is responsible for the skin barrier function. Ichthyosis vulgaris happens when the skin doesn’t shed the dead skin cells. This leads to dry, dead skin cells that accumulate in small patches on the surface of the skin, especially on the arms and legs. It’s also called the “fish scale disease” due to the dead skin that accumulates in the same pattern as a fish’s scales, as shown in the image below. But this term is no longer used, as it can be offensive to the patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient is suggested to undergo surgery for shoulder dislocation. Which of the following nerve block is recommended?
questions.solution:
Interscalene block is recommended for the surgical procedures involving the shoulder.

In interscalene block, the blockade occurs at the level of the superior and middle trunks of brachial plexus. It is performed by injecting a local anesthetic to the nerves of the brachial plexus as it passes through the groove between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Advantages of this block include rapid blockade of the shoulder region, and relatively easily palpable anatomical landmarks.

Disadvantages of this block include inadequate anesthesia in the distribution of the ulnar nerve, which makes this an unreliable block for operations involving the forearm and hand.

Image below depicts an interscalene block.

Other options:

Option A: Indications for a supraclavicular block are operations on the elbow, forearm, and hand. Blockade occurs at the distal trunk-proximal division level.

Image below depicts a supraclavicular block.

Option B: Infraclavicular block provides anesthesia to the arm and hand. Blockade occurs at the level of the cords.

Image below shows an infraclavicular block.

Option D: Indications for axillary block include surgery to the forearm and hand. Elbow procedures are also performed. Blockade occurs at the level of the terminal nerves. Although blockade of the musculocutaneous nerve is not always produced with this approach, it can be supplemented at the level of the axilla or at the elbow.

Image below depicts an axillary block.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus Blocks

 

Name of Block Level of Block Adequate Analgesia Seen at Limitations
Interscalene Superior and middle trunk Shoulder and upper arm. Most intense effect at C5-C7 dermatomes. Ulnar nerve (C8,T1) sparing
Supraclavicular Distal trunk and proximal division Elbow, forearm and hand Axillary and suprascapular nerve sparing; Pneumothorax, phrenic nerve palsy
Infraclavicular Cords Elbow, forearm and hand Intercostobrachial nerve sparing
Axillary Terminal nerves

Forearm and hand.

  • Most intense block in C7-T1 (Ulnar nerve) distribution
  • Least intense in C5-C6 dermatome
  • Most optimal for procedures from elbow to hand

 

 Musculocutaneous, axillary, medial cutaneous nerve branches sparing; Inadvertent intravascular injection

questions.text: When an ion on one side of a membrane cannot diffuse through the membrane, the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable is affected in a predictable way. This is given by______
questions.solution:
Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a nondiffusible (protein) ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves (K+ and Cl-) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

  • Other options:
    • Nernst equation→ Calculation of equilibrium potential
    • Goldmann equation→ Calculation of diffusion potential when permeable to several different ions.
    • Henderson equation (Henderson – Hasselbach equation)→ Calculation of pH (acid-base balance).

questions.text: Sodium 2-mercapto ethane sulfonate is used to reduce toxicity of
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis due to its toxic metabolite acrolein.

Hemorrhagic cystitis adverse effect can be ameliorated by systemically administering mesna (sodium 2-mercapto ethane sulfonate) or by local irrigation of bladder with acetylcysteine.

Both are -SH containing compounds that combine with and detoxify the toxic metabolites.

questions.text: Identify the correct match
questions.solution:
McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia - A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Other options:

  • Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth.
  • Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).
  • Pringle maneuver is used for minimizing blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum).

questions.text: Madelung deformity results in which of the following deformities at the wrist?
questions.solution:
Madelung deformity is an abnormality of the palmar ulnar part of the distal radial physis.

It consists of :

  • volar subluxation of hand ( dinner fork deformity)
  • the distal end of ulna is prominent
  • volar and ulnar angulation of distal radius

questions.text: The given ECG most likely suggests a diagnosis of
questions.solution:
The given ECG is characteristic of WPW syndrome - type A pattern :

  • Sinus rhythm with a very short PR interval (< 120 ms).
  • Broad QRS complexes with a slurred upstroke to the QRS complex — the delta wave.
  • Dominant R wave in V1 — this pattern is known as “Type A” WPW and is associated with a left-sided accessory pathway.
  • Tall R waves and inverted T waves in V1-3 mimicking right ventricular hypertrophy — these changes are due to WPW and do not indicate underlying RVH.
  • Negative delta wave in aVL simulating the Q waves of lateral infarction — this is referred to as the “pseudo-infarction” pattern.

WPW syndrome Type B

  • Sinus rhythm with very short PR interval (< 120 ms)
  • Broad QRS complexes with a slurred upstroke to the QRS complexes — the delta wave
  • Dominant S wave in V1 — this pattern is known as “Type B” WPW and indicates a right-sided accessory pathway
  • Tall R waves and inverted T waves in the inferior leads and V4-6 mimic the appearance of left ventricular hypertrophy — again, this is due to WPW and does not indicate underlying LVH

Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) Syndrome

  • Proposed pre-excitation syndrome
  • Accessory pathway composed of James fibres
  • ECG features:
    • PR interval <120ms
    • Normal QRS morphology
  • The term should not be used in the absence of paroxysmal tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of medial malleolus fracture?
questions.solution: • The most common complication of medial malleolus fracture is non-union. This is usually due to interposed soft tissue in the form of periosteum or the tibialis posterior tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following is one of the main compounds used in the pharmacotherapy of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children?
questions.solution: • Methylphenidate and amphetamines are the active ingredients that are widely used in drugs for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). These psychostimulant compounds resemble catecholamine neurotransmitters, dopamine and norepinephrine; by which they increase CNS activity in the brain.

questions.text: The pes anserinus is formed by all of the following muscles except ______
questions.solution:
• Pes anserinus (Also known as goose foot) refers to the conjoined tendons of three muscles, the sartorius, gracilis and semitendinosus, that insert onto the anteromedial (front and inside) surface of the proximal extremity of the tibia.
  • The pes anserinus lies superficial to the tibial insertion of the medial collateral ligament of the knee.

Clinical significance:

  • Injury or overuse of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus may lead to a condition called "pes anserine bursitis".

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Case control study cannot be used for rare diseases
Attrition is high in cohort studies
Incidence can be measured in case control studies
Cohort studies are backward looking studies

questions.solution:
• Attrition is high in cohort studies as it is a forward looking study and people tend to drop out.
  • Case control studies are used for rare diseases and incidence cannot be calculated from them.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Which of the following has to be subjected to histopathological examination to exclude malignant change if recurrence occurs
questions.solution:
Chronic non-suppurative infection of Meibomian gland is chalazion. (Image below)

Recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathology because of possible malignant change into Meibomian gland adenocarcinoma / sebaceous cell carcinoma in old age.

Chalazion

It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of Meibomian gland

  • Presents as a painless swelling of the eye lid
  • Treatment
    • Incision and curettage
    • Intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate
  • Hordeolum internum is a suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland associated with blockage of the duct.
  • Hordeolum externum or stye is staphylococcal infection of hair follicle / Zeis gland / Moll gland.

questions.text: The definition of blindness according to the latest revision by NPCB is visual acuity
questions.solution:
The definition of Blindness under the National Programme for Control of  Blindnes (NPCB) is modified  in line with WHO Definition :

"Presenting distance visually acuity less then 3/60  in the better eye and limitation of field of vision to be less than 10 degrees from centre of fixation ".

Note:

The nomenclature of the scheme is also changed  from 'National Programme for Control of Blindness' to  'National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment' .

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding multiple sclerosis?

choices.text: Marburg’s variant refers to chronic relapsing form of disease
Shadow plaques refer to demyelinated axon in central nervous system
Vitamin D deficiency is associated with increased risk of MS

questions.solution:
Vitamin D deficiency is a risk factor for development of MS.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system (CNS) typically presenting with relapsing and remitting symptoms.

The presentation may be abrupt or insidious with variable intensity of symptoms depending upon the location. MS plaques typically develop at different times and at different CNS locations (i.e., MS is said to be disseminated in time and space). It is three times more common in women than men with the age of onset being 20 to 40 years. Risk factors for MS include

  1. Genetic predisposition
  2. Vitamin D deficiency
  3. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) exposure after early childhood
  4. HLA-DRB1 gene
  5. Cigarette smoking

Other options

Option A: Acute Multiple Sclerosis (Marburg’s variant) is a fulminant, demyelinating process that in some cases progresses inexorably to death within 1–2 years.

Option B: Histopathologically, partial and incomplete remyelination by surviving oligodendrocytes is represented as shadow plaques.

Option D: MRI is the imaging of choice. It demonstrates increased vascular permeability, multifocal hyperintense lesions. Dawson's fingers may be present which are areas of perivenous demyelination that are seen as lesions that are perpendicular to the ventricle. They appear as hyperintense areas on the T2-weighted images.

questions.text: All of the following are false regarding the "triangle of safety" for the insertion of a chest drain except

choices.text: At the level of the nipple
Below and medial to the pectoralis muscle

questions.solution:
The triangle of safety is the safest site for the insertion of a chest drain.

Relations of triangle of safety:

  • Anterior to mid-axillary line
  • Above the level of the nipple
  • Below and lateral to pectoralis major muscle

 

This will ideally find the 5th space. The technique includes the following:

  • Meticulous attention to sterility throughout
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura
  • Sharp dissection only to cut the skin
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers (serratus anterior and intercostals)
  • An oblique tract so the skin incision and hole in the parietal pleura don’t overlie each other
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim for the apex of lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle
  • Retaining stitch should be secure and not obliterate the drain
  • The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve

After completion a chest X-Ray should be taken to confirm the drain has achieved its objective

questions.text: A child is below 3rd percentile for height. His growth velocity is normal, and chronological age is equal to skeletal age. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario depicts:

  • Short stature
  • Normal variant of short stature
  • Skeletal age = Chronological age

This is characteristic of Familial short stature

The 2 types of Normal variant of short stature are :

  • Constitutional delay: – Bone age < Chronological age
  • Familial short stature: – Bone age = Chronological age

Features of constitutional delay:

  • Most common cause
  • Ultimate height attained is normal
  • Growth velocity is normal
  • Bone age < Chronological age
  • IGF -1 levels remain low for chronological age

Features of familial short stature :

  • Growth velocity is normal
  • Family history of short stature positive
  • Bone age = Chronological age
  • Puberty is normal

Final height attained is low but normal for target height

questions.text: Identify the correct match.
questions.solution:
Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for anal fissure at present.

An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate line and extending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic. Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with:

  • Anal pain
  • Spasm
  • Bleeding with defecation

The initial treatment of anal fissures includes: Frequent sitz baths, analgesics, stool softners and high-fiber diet.

Other options include topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted. 

Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique. 

Other options:

Option a: Delorme procedure is for rectal prolapse.

Option b: Seton procedure is for fistula in ano.

Option d: Nigro regimen is for anal carcinoma.

questions.text: Tendonitis and tendon rupture are associated with the use of
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones are associated with increased risk of tendinitis and tendon ruptureespecially in elderly people but can affect any age group.

Fluoroquinolones should be stopped at the first sign of tendon rupture

questions.text: All are true regarding the condition shown below except:

choices.text: It is more prevalent in women than in men
According to the CEAP classification, the above condition belongs to class C3
Their distribution indicates which superficial system is defective
The duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for this condition

questions.solution:
The above image shows presence of varicosities without edema, skin changes or ulcers. Class C2 indicates varicose veins and C3 indicates edema.

The prevalence of varicose veins is 25-30% in women, and 15% in men.

Distribution of varicosities indicate which superficial system is defective:

  • Medial thigh and calf varicosities indicate long saphenous incompetence
  • Posterolateral calf varicosities indicate short saphenous vein incompetence
  • Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities indicate isolated incompetence of proximal anterolateral long saphenous tributary

Duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for varicose veins.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with features of parkinsonism and cerebellar features. An MRI brain was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI characteristically shows the pontine hot cross bun sign which is highly suggestive of multiple system atrophy.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease. Along with the features of Parkinson's disease, they also have cerebellar and autonomic features. The common autonomic feature seen in these patients is orthostatic hypotension. MSA is characterized by the presence of degeneration in the striatum, cerebellum, and inferior olivary nuclei coupled with characteristic glial cytoplasmic inclusions. These inclusions stain positively for α-synuclein.

It is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P: T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hypointensity due to iron deposition
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Other options:

Option A: Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring balance. 

Option C: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted vertical eye movements with downward gaze palsy. Patients also have hyperextension of the neck with gait disturbances and frequent falls. MRI may reveal characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with normal pons. This is called a hummingbird sign. There is degeneration of the striatum, subthalamic nucleus, midline thalamic nuclei, and pallidum, coupled with neurofibrillary tangles and inclusions that stain for tau protein.

Option D: Dementia pugilistica/punch drunk syndrome is post-traumatic dementia, not degenerative dementia. This occurs in boxers & football players after repeated head trauma over many years. It is characterized by emotional lability, dysarthria, and impulsivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common structure seen in all the sphingolipids?
questions.solution:
Ceramide = Sphingosine + Fatty acid

This is the basic structure found in all the sphingolipids.

Hence, ceramide is the common structure among all sphingolipids.

Glycerol is found in glycerolipids only → option a is excluded

N-acetylneuraminic acid (NANA) is found in gangliosides, not in all the sphingolipids → option c is excluded.

Phosphoryl choline is found only in sphingomyelin, not in all the sphingolipids → option d is excluded.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Sphingolipids

Glycosphingolipid

Cerebrosides

Gangliosides

Globosides

 

Oligosaccharide moiety attached to the ceramide unit

Sphingophospholipid

Sphingomyelin

Phosphate attached to the ceramide unit

questions.text: For well water in a community, a Horrock’s apparatus showed the 2nd cup turn blue first. What will be the requirement of bleaching powder for disinfecting 9100 liters of water?
questions.solution:
• The dose of bleaching powder in a Horrock’s apparatus that is required is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows distinct blue color.
  • In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water is (2 x 2) = 4 grams.
  • Since 9100/455 = 20. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 9100 litres of water = 4 x 20 = 80 grams.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: All are true about Meckel’s diverticulum except?

choices.text: Incidentally detected Meckel’s diverticulum should be treated only conservatively

questions.solution:
• An incidentally found Meckel’s diverticulum be removed at any age up to 80 years as long as no additional conditions (e.g., peritonitis) make removal hazardous.

questions.text: Asperger disorder is now under the broad category of:
questions.solution:
• As per the current updates (DM-5), autism spectrum disorder (ASD) includes a number of conditions which are characterized by early onset of severe delay in development of social and communicative skills and also the unusual response to environment.
  • It was previously grouped and named under pervasive developmental disorders.
  • This new categorization also includes Asperger disorder, pervasive developmental disorder-not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS), Rett syndrome, etc.
  • The diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are:
    1. Persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts.
    2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests or activities.
    3. Symptoms must be present in early developmental period.
    4. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational or other important areas of social functioning.
    5. These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay.
