questions.text: The most common diagnostic indication of electroconvulsive therapy is:
questions.solution: • The most common indication of electroconvulsive therapy is major depression. It also has the maximum benefit in this condition.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. An  X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation. The condition is characterized by a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad. It comprises small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gall stone).

Penumobilia refers to the presence of air within the biliary tree which suggest that there is an abnormal communication between the intestine and the biliary tract. Other conditions associated with pneumobilia include incompetent sphincter of Oddi and biliary-enteric anastomosis.

CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis.

Gall stone ileus is managed by

  • Milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Removal of the stone.\

The surgical procedures that can be performed are: simple enterolithotomy, enterolithotomy, cholecystectomy, and fistula closure (one-stage procedure) and enterolithotomy with cholecystectomy performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Option A: Cecal volvulus presents with features of obstruction. Ischaemia can be seen and the midline or a left-sided swelling can be present. On radiograph, it will show a dilated and air-filled cecum. Other clinical features such as dilated small bowel and absence of gas in the distal colon are seen. 

Option B: In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

Option C: Crohn's disease on small bowel enema shows narrowing of involved areas and is often irregular. Features include colicky postprandial abdominal pain, diarrhea, and palpable and tender right iliac fossa mass. Other less common features like fever, anemia and weight loss can be seen.

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

questions.text: Which of the following structures is spared in the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue?
questions.solution:
The posterior cruciate ligament is spared in the unhappy triad of O’Donoghue.

The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue comprises injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament,
  • Medial collateral ligament, and
  • Medial meniscus.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: All are true about AJCC 8th edition  staging of thyroid neoplasms except

choices.text: Only human cancer where age is included in staging
In staging age barrier is 55 years

questions.solution:
AJCC staging has only N0 and N1

The changes in AJCC 8th edition TNM for thyroid neoplasms

Age at diagnosis cut off for prognosis now increased to 55 year

Younger patient (<55 years) with any T or N staging with no metastasis comes under stage I and with metastasis falls under stage 2.

Minor extrathyroid extension excluded from T3

T3a – new category with >4 cms limited to thyroid

T3b- new category with any size tumor with gross extrathyroid extension only to strap muscles.

N1a includes level VI & VII

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

questions.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is present in
questions.solution:
High Anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in poorly controlled diabetes

The mnemonic MUDPILES is commonly used to remember the causes of increased anion gap metabolic acidosis :

  • M — Methanol
  • U — Uremia (chronic kidney failure)
  • D — Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • P — Paracetamol, Propylene glycol
  • I — Infection, Iron, Isoniazid, Inborn errors of metabolism
  • L — Lactic acidosis
  • E — Ethylene glycol
  • S — Salicylates

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a person with liver disease reveals the following:
paCO2= 36, HCO3- = 33, pH = 7.49, Anion gap = 16, Na+ = 140 ,  K+ = 4.0 ,  Cl-= 91
Which of the following is most likely present?
questions.solution:
The given scenario reveals Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory alkalosis.

Approach :

Step 1 :

pH = 7.49  Normal = (7.35 – 7.45) 7.4 Increased  The values clearly suggest Metabolic alkalosis
paCO2 = 36  Normal = (35 – 45) 40 Normal
HCO3- = 34  Normal = (22 – 28) 25 Increased

Step 2 :

Looking for compensation of CO2

In Metabolic alkalosis, Compensation formula is :

∆ [HCO3-] = Increase in HCO3-, in above case is  = 34 - 25 = 9

So compensatory increase of CO2 should be = 0.7 x 9 = 6.3

Applying the above, the compensation value of CO2 should lie between

40 + 6.3 = 46.3 or approx. 46

Taking +/- 3 into consideration ,  Compensatory values of CO2 = 43 – 49

Step 3 :

Since CO2 = 36 which is below the compensatory values , hence this is Not compensated.

It suggests that there is a simultaneous Respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4 :

Looking for anion gap :

Anion gap should be looked for only in cases of:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal pH

Since the primary disorder is Metabolic alkalosis, Anion gap is not looked into.

A situation like this is seen with Liver disease and Diuretics administration.

questions.text: True about CSF rhinorrhea
questions.solution:
Reservoir sign—fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.

Double target sign/halo sign/target sign – when CSF is mixed with blood, it is collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows central red spot (blood) and peripheral lighter halo. CSF can’t be sniffed back whereas nasal secretions can be.

CSF doesn’t stiffen handkerchief but nasal secretions stiffen handkerchief due to mucus content.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/coalescent Mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappears in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: Vitamin E deficiency is associated with all except
questions.solution:
Exfoliative dermatitis is not a feature of Vitamin E deficiency.

Vitamin E deficiency is characterised by :

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Areflexia
  • Progression to an ataxic gait
  • Decreased vibration and position sensations
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Skeletal myopathy
  • Pigmented retinopathy

questions.text: A resident doctor sustained a needlestick injury while sampling blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the following would be the best recommendation?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

The protocol followed is :Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28 - day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

Note: The NACO October 2018 guidelines recommend the two drug regimen but the recent MOHFW JAN 2020 recommends the three drug regimen as per WHO December 2018 guidelines as the preferred treatment for PEP in HIV.

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: Sensory supply of larynx below the level of vocal cord is
questions.solution: Above the vocal cords, larynx is supplied by internal laryngeal nerve—a branch of superior laryngeal, and below the vocal cords by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A patient with shoulder pain was examined and Yergason’s test was found to be positive. Which structure is likely to be the source of the pain?
questions.solution:
• The Yergason sign/test is also called the supination sign. A positive Yergason test indicates inflammation arising from the long head of the biceps.
  • In this test, the elbow is flexed to 90 degrees and the forearm is pronated. The patient then attempts to supinate the forearm actively against resistance
  • This test is negative with complete or partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

questions.text: Gillette’s space is
questions.solution: Retropharyngeal space is divided into two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) by a fibrous raphe.

questions.text: The most common cause of painless limp in a 7-year-old is:
questions.solution:
• The typical average age of presentation of Perthes disease is 7 years. There is a painless limp in Perthes disease. Thus, the most common cause of painless limp in a 7 year old is Legg-Calve-Perthes disease.
  • TB hip presents with a painful limp.
  • DDH presents earlier in life, around 3 years of age.
